PROCTEXT.PARA: The Senate met at 10 a.m.
The Clerk-Honourable senators, the President is unable to attend the sitting of the Senate today. In accordance with standing order 29, the Deputy President will take the chair.
The DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Hamer) thereupon took the chair, and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Human Embryo Experimentation Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honorouble the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned shows:
That human embryos deserve legal protection to enable the development of their full human potential.
Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembed, should:
Pass Senator Harradine's Bill to prohibit experiments involving the use of human embryos created by in vitro fertilization.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will every pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Giles (from 315 citizens), Robertson (from 89 citizens) and Walsh (from 172 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Discrimination against Women
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembed:
Victoria Planning (Brothels) Act 1984
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That whereas the Commonwealth of Australia ratified the UN Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women in 1983, the Government of Victoria in passing the Planning (Brothels) Act 1984 is in breach of Article 6 of the Convention which says that `States Parties shall take all appropriate measures, including legislation, to suppress all forms of traffic in women and exploitation of prostitution of women'.
That the Victorian Planning (Brothels) Act 1984 provides legal authority to brothel operators to traffic in and exploit the prostitution of women and to live off the earnings of prostitutes.

That whereas the Federal Minister for Health has counselled citizens to shun promiscuity (The Australian 26/1/85) because of the serious and sometimes fatal heatlh hazards, the operations of legalised brothels encourages promiscuity and the spread of diseases, including AIDS.
Your petitioners therefore pray:

That the Government of Australia having ratified the UN Convention on Women remain consistent in its obligations to uphold the Articles of the Convention and request the Victorian Government to immediately repeal the Planning (Brothels) Act 1984.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will every pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Gareth Evans (from 497 citizens) and Short (from 231 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Identification Cards
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembed.
The petition of the undersigned shows:
That the proposed introduction of compulsory identification (ID) cards should be reconsidered and rejected because the system:
(a) is not a cost-effective method of reducing tax evasion and social security fraud and, to the contrary, in the form proposed will facilitate such evasion and fraud;
(b) will constitute an unwarranted infringment of individual privacy by the aggregation of a wide variety of personal information of a private nature;
(c) will cause a further large and costly growth in the bureaucracy and burden on the taxpayer;
(d) cannot be guaranteed against misuse for purposes other than for which their introduction is stated to be intended and in fact provide the opportunity for blackmail and other forms of misuse.
And your petitioners humbly pray that the problems which identification cards are intended to reduce should be attacked by other, more effective and less obnoxious methods.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Human Embryo Experimentation Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the understated citizens of Australia respectfully showeth-That we the undersigned have great concern for the future development and research of the IVF program and express that we are against `Senator Harradine's Bill' Human Embryo Experimental Bill 1985.
The Bill threatens the provisions as a treatment for infertility because it defines as `prohibited experimentation':
1. Any manipulation of a relevant human embryo;
2. Any procedure undertaken on, or involving the use of, a relevant human embryo;

3. The creating of a relevant human embryo in anticipation that the development of the full human potential of the relevant human embryo will be interrupted or of using the embryo, or of having the embryo available for use, in any experimenting by virtue of sub-section (1) shall be deemed to be prohibited experimenting for the purposes of this Act;
4. Wilfully destroy a relevant human embryo;
5. Wilfully allow a relevant human embryo to die.

PETITION.TITLE: Belconnen Mall, Canberra
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament.
We the undersigned express our concern over the sale of the Belconnen Mall due to the likely detrimental effect on the provision of community facilities presently existing in the Belconnen Mall.

1. In particular we seek guarantees that the present child care centre and community facilities be retained by incorporating the same into the conditions of sale of the Belconnen Mall and that the services will receive the same real level of funding and support currently provided by the Canberra Commercial Development Authority.

2. That a financial commitment to the Building of Stage 4 of the Belconnen Mall listed under Section 14C in the Ordinance of the Canberra Commercial Development Authority be undertaken. Stage 4 to consist of community facilities such as community hall, large glassed enclosed community park, exhibition space, health and fitness club, ice rink, amusement centre and office accommodation.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that this petition be considered.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Protected Wildlife: Prohibited Experimentation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament House assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that we believe that our protected wildlife are not suitable subjects for laboratory experimentation and that repetitive and needless experiments should be prohibited.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will every pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Interest Rates
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of we the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
The unrelenting ever expending money extortion to which home purchasers are being subjected has exceeded the bounds of all logical reason. It is neither linear or progressive.

It becomes transparently clear that the constant edging up of interest rates for investors by banks, lending institutions, and banking consortiums are collectively responsible for the monetary explosion, lack of employment and all that entails and is causing grave social disruption to hundreds of thousands. Behind it all, the absence of control that is now politically essential in the interest of justice and fair distribution of burden.
No government, recent or future should tolerate this cruel, vicious procedure that shatters the existence of family life, together with all the well known disastrous repercussions that follow.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your House urge all politicians to unite nationally to do all within their power to reduce interest rates across the board and that:

This country needs a five-year period to reduce this unwarranted absurdity by tackling its source, as follows: firstly a 2 per cent annual interest reduction on home loans, until it is down to 6 per cent. This to come into force immediately subject to the urgent necessary legislation.

This would, or should curtail union demands, and cause no hazard for investors, who could reinvest in Government projects, or other worthwhile ventures. It would also certainly ease the burden on social securities.
Your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Nursing Home Benefits
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled; the humble petition of the undersigned citizens of South Australia respectfully showeth that:

Without any warning and at the worst possible moment, the Federal Government has abandoned the pensioner patients in South Australia's Nursing Homes. These people are suffering undeserving hardship and trauma as a result of the Federal Government's decision to freeze the nursing home benefit levels in South Australia.

The pensioner patients and those on fixed incomes now cannot expect any relief from recent significant fee increases approved by the Department of Community Services and which have coincided with the decision to freeze benefits.

80-85 per cent of nursing home patients are pensioners and the majority are now required to pay in excess of their pension for their nursing care for the very first time. Some are paying over $5 per day on top of their pension. Many are looking for cheaper nursing care that doesn't exist.
We request that the Federal Government:

1. alleviate the distress of South Australia's nursing home patients and their families by effective restoration of the principle that pensioner patients should not have to pay more than their pension for nursing home care
2. restore the review of the benefit rates in November 1985
3. resolve its concerns over health care costs with the South Australian Government rather than inflicting unnecessary suffering on nursing home patients.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Plant Variety Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
We the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth do humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government:

1. Uphold the principle that the seeds and cuttings of plants are a public resource and a common heritage to all and that accordingly seeds should be freely available to all, freely multipliable, able to be sold, exchanged, exported and imported by anyone who wishes. This is seen as a matter of national food security.

2. Recognise that plant breeding is a highly co-operative venture often involving private enterprise at the very last stages after basic seed collection, storage, and research has been publicly funded.
3. In view of the aforementioned paragraphs, recognise that any system giving `property' or ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises is inappropriate and unjust.
4. Recognise that legislation establishing plant patenting schemes overseas has had serious adverse effects namely:
i. a slowing-down of scientific information exchange and exchanges in basic plant breeding materials, that is, germ plasm,
ii. subordination and/or curtailment of public breeding programs,
iii. farmer unrest at seed prices,
iv. monopoly control of seed production and sales has passed into the hands of giant petrochemical and drug corporations also marketing crop chemicals,
v. increased uniformity of crop varieties leading to a vulnerability to pest and disease attack.
5. Reject any proposal to legislate for any system such as the drafted Plant Variety Rights Act, which gives exclusive ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Foreign Military and Intelligence Facilities in Australia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that:

1. The Watsonia Army Barracks contains electronic communication facilities, operated by Australian and American personnel, that gives the United States the ability to pin-point Soviet nuclear submarines, hidden in the Oceans.

2. This would make it possible for US killer-submarines to destroy all Soviet nuclear submarines, while the US nuclear submarines launch their missiles in a `first strike' attack. This makes Watsonia a potential nuclear target. A nuclear attack on Watsonia would have a disastrous effect on Melbourne.
3. The `joint US-Australian' bases in Australia endanger rather than protect us. They also add a new menace to nuclear arms race, that must be stopped.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should close the `joint Australian-US' electronic communication facilities in the Watsonia Army Barracks.

PETITION.TITLE: Pre-School and Child Care Services: Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth that we deplore the proposed cut-back of funding for pre-school and child care in the mini-budget as the proposal adversely affects young families, women's employment prospects and children's development in their most formative years.
We urge you to reverse proposals for cuts in children's services.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

DEBATE.TITLE: POSTAL SERVICES AMENDMENT (CONTINUANCE OF POSTAL SERVICES) BILL 1985

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Archer for Senator Lewis) agreed to:

That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act to amend the Postal Services Act 1975 to allow for the continuance of postal services when the Australian Postal Commission is not able effectively to provide those services.
Bill presented by Senator Archer, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

Section 85 of the Postal Services Act gives Australia Post a monopoly on the carriage of letters weighing 500 grams or less. Breach of this monopoly carries a fine of $1,000. The consequence of this monopoly is that when Australia Post is unable to provide a service for the carriage of such letters Australians have no legal alternative means of having their letters delivered. This Bill amends section 85 to give the Minister for Communications a power to waive the monopoly provision at such times. An example when this power would have been of benefit to the Australian community was during the recent mail sorters' strike in New South Wales. In this respect, it is worth remembering that 40 per cent of Australia's mail passes through N.S.W. Articles weighing over 500 grams are unaffected by this monopoly and are freely carried by specialist courier services. At times (and particularly during postal disputes) courier services are circumventing the letter momopoly by carrying letters in large cardboard satchels weighing a minimum 500 grams. This questionable practice is inefficient, and is a service available only to the more affluent sections of the community.

The principal reason for the Bill is that a legal monopoly is justifiable only if it enables a cheap and efficient service to be provided to consumers. When Australia Post is unable to provide a reasonably efficient service for whatever reason, there can be no justification for retaining that monopoly and it should be removed. In addition, the waiving of the monopoly to meet such an exigency would:

force the Government and the Minister to be responsible for provision of postal services. At present the Minister is able to avoid responsibility by claiming that Australia Post is a Statutory Authority and should be protected from ``government interference'';

put pressure on the Minister to exercise the powers conferred on him under section 8 (1) of the Postal Services Act to give to the Commission, in writing, such directions as to the performance of its functions and the exercise of its powers as appear to be necessary in the public interest;
encourage militant postal workers to seek to resolve industrial disputes by negotiation rather than by strike action;
encourage Australia Post to prevent and settle industrial disputes by forcing it to face loss of business and potential loss of revenue during strikes;
reduce the incidence of breaches of the law by couriers using inefficient and artificial contrivances-breaches to which Australia Post currently turns a blind eye.

The legislation provides that where the Minister, after consultation with the Commission, is satisfied that, by reason of an industrial dispute or for any other reason, the Commission is unable to operate its postal services in such a manner as will meet the social, industrial and commercial needs of the Australian people for postal services, whether throughout Australia or in a particular part of Australia, the Minister may suspend the monopoly provision.

During the period of the suspension of the monopoly provision a letter may be carried for reward by persons other than the Commission from a place within Australia for delivery at a place within or outside Australia or from a place outside Australia for delivery within Australia. In the current climate it is clear that this Bill would have widespread support. The business community and editorial writers have indicated support. The Major Mail Users of Australia, representing more than 20 per cent-in excess of $200m-of Australia Post's revenue, is determined the Minister should face up to his responsibilities. It's Chairman, Mr Malcolm Overland, has been seeking to see the Minister and has been told by his office in no uncertain terms that the Minister would see him when he was good and ready. Australia Post management could be concerned that this might be the ``thin end of the wedge'' leading to complete removal of its monopoly provisions and a consequent erosion of its revenue base. This amendment is not likely to have significant revenue implications except in a prolonged dispute.

At the opening of a new Post Office at Wodonga in March this year the Minister, however, acknowledged that ``. . . If service quality in New South Wales continues to fail then growth in demand for Post services will decline as dissatisfied customers go elsewhere. The consequences of such a decline could well be catastrophic for the whole organisation''. Australia's mail services are chaotic, and recent bans and strikes have been causing massive financial and personal hardship to businesses and private individuals around the country. Because it is not faced with competition, Australia Post cannot go broke, and this weak Government will not take action for fear of offending the ACTU. This legislation will enable a responsible Government to ensure that ``the mail gets through'' notwithstanding industrial problems. If that should happen there will be a massive sigh of relief around Australia.
Debate (on motion by Senator Button) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Button) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

This Bill seeks to make a number of important changes in a variety of fields relating to the health portfolio. First, the Bill proposes substantial amendments to the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories Act 1961, to increase the competitive ability and the autonomy of the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories. Second, it proposes significant reforms to the medi-fraud provisions of the Health Insurance Act. Third, it provides, under a sunset clause, for the Health Insurance Commission to undertake planning for the Australia card programme. Finally, it provides for a number of amendments mainly of a technical nature to various aspects of the health function.

May I first draw the attention of honourable senators to Part II of the Bill which is intended to streamline greatly the day-to-day operations and to improve the commercial viability of the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories (CSL) Commission. The need for these important changes has become apparent since the CSL Act was last amended in 1980, following an independent inquiry into the Commission's operations and capital works. These changes are the most significant changes to the structure and operations of CSL in its sixty-nine year history. Clause 10 of the Bill seeks to enable CSL to make use of idle production facilities and resources when they are not being used for pharmaceutical production. The additional use of CSL's facilities in this way will, of course, decrease the overall cost of oper- ations to the Commonwealth. Clause 11 will allow the Commission to undertake a number of normal commercial activities such as forming a company, buying and selling of shares, or entering into a profit-sharing partnership. This clause removes a current constraint on CSL which is not imposed on its competitors and is intended to make the Commission more commercially viable in a highly competitive industry. I would point out that any transactions of this nature will require the minister's approval where CSL will have a controlling interest. Clause 20 provides for possible reimbursement to the Commission if, as a result of a direction given to it by the ministers, it suffers a financial loss.
Other provisions in the Bill are designed to help the Commission improve its efficiency, effectiveness and accountability. I will briefly outline some of these matters:
The current constraint which prevents any person with a direct or indirect interest in any pharmaceutical enterprise from appointment as a CSL Commissioner is to be removed;

The term of appointment for commissioners is to be changed from the current four years to not less than three and not more than five years. These two changes will broaden the range of people eligible and available for appointment;
A legislative requirement for declaration of interests by Commissioners is being introduced, formalising a practice which has existed for many years;

The Commission's director, whose title is to be changed to managing director, will in future be appointed by the Commission itself, rather than by the Governor-General. Such changes recognise the importance of the chief executive officer and the controlling body of a government authority which is expected to be competitive and commercially viable and to play a leading role in public health in Australia;

In relation to Commission staff, the requirement for Public Service Board approval of staff terms and conditions is removed-a necessary step to allow the Commission to be more innovative and competitive in the labour market-place;

The Minister will be required to consult with the Commission before giving it any written direction which will affect its operations; such direction will have to be published in the Commonwealth Gazette within 21 days;
The Commission is to be covered by the general provisions of the Audit Act 1901 in relation to its accountability;

These are the principal changes proposed in the part of the Bill relating to the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories Commission-changes which will enhance the operations and the commercial effectiveness of the Commission. In relation to the financial impact of the changes, in only one area is there any possibility of a cost to the Government. I refer to the possible reimbursement to the Commission for any financial loss resulting from a direction given by the Minister. Such a direction would be given only as a last resort following consultation with the Commission and after other avenues of action in accordance with the legislation had been exhausted. It is impossible to quantify such a cost-it would depend entirely on the circumstances at the time. On the other hand, an increase in revenue for the Government is expected. The improved commercial viability of the Commission should produce increased dividends. In addition cost savings for the Government can be expected from the increased use of production facilities. These changes will further prove the advantages to Australian citizens of having a public window into the pharmaceutical industry.

I now turn to a number of provisions in the Bill which propose amendments to the Health Insurance Act. Section 3B of the Act currently provides for the issue of a certificate by a medical practitioner stating that a person is in need of acute hospital care for a period of up to 35 days. The section ensures that full benefits are paid for long-term acute care hospital patients. Without this certification all patients are automatically classified as `nursing home type patients' after 35 days in hospital and their health fund benefits are reduced accordingly. Experience has shown that for various reasons, medical practitioners sometimes fail to furnish certificates at the appropriate time. As there is currently no retrospectivity allowed by the legislation, some acute care patients have been financially disadvantaged through reduction of their hospital benefits to nursing home levels. It must be pointed out however, that the health insurance industry has behaved most responsibly in this area, and has usually made ex gratia benefit payments in such circumstances.

Clause 28 of this Bill proposes that retrospective certification be allowed; it has the support of the health insurance and private hospital industries, and of the Australian Medical Association. The amendment will correct a current anomaly under which the health funds cannot share the liability for ex gratia patients via the reinsurance arrangements. Commonwealth outlays will not be affected, as the Commonwealth bed-day subsidy continues to be paid whether the patient is classified as `nursing home type' or `acute care'.

The Bill proposes a further change to this section of the Health Insurance Act-an amendment of the definition of `nursing home type patient' in sub-clause 26 (2) and a provision in clause 27-which together enable the Secretary to the Department of Health to exclude individual patients or classes of patients from the nursing home type patients arrangements. This would be done through a determination which would be subject to parliamentary scrutiny and disallowance. To ensure proper consideration of the medical circumstances of each case, the determination power would be delegated to senior Commonwealth medical officers within the Health Department. The development of a review process through the Acute Care Advisory Committee arrangements, plus monitoring of the nursing home type patient arrangements, has pointed to some justification for the exclusion of certain types of patients from those arrangements. These might include, for example, certain long-term acute care psychiatric patients and terminally ill cancer patients.

The types of patients who might be covered by this amendment are to be discussed with the medical profession and the health insurance organisations before any individual or class of exclusion is declared. The purpose of this amendment is to provide an appropriate mechanism to allow an exclusion of general classes of patients, whereas currently only individual exclusions are permitted. Again there will be no effect on Commonwealth outlays, nor will health insurance organisations be affected as it is intended that any excluded class of patients would be those to whom section 3B certificates now routinely apply. There should be a small administrative saving through a reduction in the numbers of certificates issued by doctors and monitored by the health funds.

Clause 37 will amend section 20 of the Health Insurance Act to empower the General Manager of the Health Insurance Commission to determine how Medicare benefits should be paid. The new provision is similar to one in the social security legislation.

The Commission has always followed a policy of limiting cash payments for Medicare claims at its branch offices, with benefits above a certain sum paid by cheque and sent to the claimant within a few days. It has adopted this policy, which is similar to that of other health insurance organisations, for sound business reasons. First, the Commission's experience over many years indicates that for large amounts the use of cheques posted to a valid address acts as a deterrent to claimant fraud. Secondly, cash limits enable the Commission to estimate reliably a branch's cash needs for a day's trading, with advantages both to the Commission's clients and its own operations. Thirdly, the limiting of cash required to be held overnight at branch offices reduces their attractiveness as possible targets for robbery. The Commission believes its policy is soundly based and prudent, and through this Bill seeks to ensure that the policy is reflected and supported by legislation. At the same time it is very mindful of its responsibility not to disadvantage claimants in genuine hardship. Branch managers will continue to have the discretion of paying larger benefit claims in cash or by an immediate cheque.

The Bill also facilitates the implementation of a Government commitment, foreshadowed in the 1984 election policy speech, to ``extend Medicare to provide reciprocal health care arrangements for countries with which Australia has close ties''. As Honourable Senators may be aware, negotiations to this end have since begun with the United Kingdom, Italy, Spain, Greece, Yugoslavia, Eire and New Zealand. Reciprocal agreements will allow short-term visitors from such countries to Australia access to hospital and medical services for medical conditions requiring urgent treatment, just as Australian visitors to those countries will have similar rights. The agreements will also provide full access, for Australian diplomatic and consular staff and their families, to the national health schemes in those countries with which agreements are reached. This Bill amends the Health Insurance Act so that diplomatic and consular staff and their families posted to Australia will be entitled to full access to Medicare.

I turn now to those provisions of the Bill which propose changes in relation to the recognition of medical specialists in Australia. By virtue of clauses 29 and 44 the Bill seeks to simplify and streamline the arrangements whereby practitioners are recognised as specialists for the purposes of the Health Insurance Act. At present this is undertaken by ministerial reference to a Specialist Recognition Advisory Committee which takes into account an applicant's qualifications, experience and standing in the medical profession, together with the nature of his or her practice. Under the new arrangements, practitioners will, in general, be automatically recognised as specialists if they are fellows of specified specialist colleges and they have an appropriate qualification obtained by successfully completing a prescribed course of study; or if they are registered as specialists under the Laws of the States or Territories.

The Minister will retain the right to refer applicants as at present to a Specialist Recognition Advisory Committee where automatic recognition does not appear appropriate. Among other proposed changes are the following:
recognition is to apply on a national basis rather than be restricted to the State or Territory of residence or practice;
there is to be a capacity to place a limit on the period of recognition of overseas practitioners temporarily requiring specialist or consultant physician recognition in Australia.

The Bill provides that to offset administrative costs a fee-of $30, to be prescribed by regulation-should accompany each application. This fee will produce estimated annual revenue of some $16 500. The more streamlined handling of applications from fellows of specified colleges will result in some small savings. In relation to the $30 fee, I would make the point that recognition as a specialist or consultant physician entitles the practitioner to receive higher rebates for his or her services under Medicare.

The Bill before the Senate proposes a number of changes to the penalty and disqualification provisions of the Health Insurance Act. These changes represent the most significant amendments contained in the Bill. Honourable Senators will recall that the present provisions were introduced three years ago as part of the previous Government's approach to medical benefits fraud-an approach which proved to be unreasonably rigid and insensitive and, in some cases, unnecessarily harsh. The proposed new arrangements address a number of the shortcomings of the existing provisions. Before outlining the major features, let me first reiterate the Government's firm view that it is only a minority of practitioners who abuse the Medicare system and bring dishonour to their profession. I have no doubt that the great majority of practitioners will support this initiative.

Under the current legislation there is no distinction between the penalties applying to practitioners found guilty of medifraud offences regardless of whether the offence was intentional or the result of reckless or gross careless conduct. Whatever the circumstance, disqualification from participation in Medicare applies automatically for three years, where two or more offences are found proven. The Minister does have power to moderate such disqualifications. However, this power is limited only to situations where special circumstances exist, particularly with regard to patient welfare. Thus, moderation cannot be given where the facts otherwise indicate that it would be reasonable to do so.

Another shortcoming relates to the recovery of benefits wrongfully paid. There is currently no specific provision in the Health Insurance Act relating to recovery and, as a matter of equity, the Government has been able to recover only those overpaid benefits paid directly to a practitioner. Recovery from innocent patients is clearly not acceptable. Further, the counselling of practitioners-a particularly effective means of ensuring that doctors fully understand their legal obligations-has been jeopardised by a growing belief that in the absence of privilege for their confidential discussions with medical counsellors prosecution could ensue.
This Bill addresses each of these problems. It proposes a more flexible system for dealing with both wilful and innocent misstatements by practitioners with these major provisions:
The recovery of wrongfully paid benefits from the person responsible for making the false or misleading statement associated with the claim;
The introduction of a summary offence provision for the making of false or misleading statements and of an indictable offence provision for knowingly making false or misleading statements; and

The establishment of a new, independent medicare participation review committee which is to determine whether the services of offending practitioners should continue to be eligible for medicare benefits.

The new recovery provisions will apply in all cases where an overpayment has occurred as a result of misitemisation or other misstatement. It will also provide a means of recovery from the practitioner in cases where the practitioner is responsible for the misstatement but the claim has been lodged by the patient. Decisions to recover will be made at a senior level in the Health Insurance Commission. Wherever practicable, recovery will be achieved by negotiation between the Health Insurance Commission and the practitioner concerned, but the Bill does recognise the right to pursue or contest recovery of a debt in civil proceedings. The Bill also provides for interest to be payable on outstanding debts in cases where a practitioner either refuses after official notification of a debt to make restitution within a specified time or defaults on an agreement to repay. Similar provisions will apply where recovery becomes the subject of civil court proceedings.

New offence provisions introduced by the Bill provide that the making of a false or misleading statement will become a statutory, but summary, offence. It will not be necessary for the Crown to prove intent, but a statutory defence is available to a defendant who can establish, on the balance of probabilities, that he or she did not know, and could not reasonably have been expected to know, that either the statement was false or misleading or was capable of being used for obtaining benefits. The Bill also includes a protection against double jeopardy, by specifically prohibiting the punishment of a person under more than one provision in the Health Insurance Act in respect of the same offence.

Prosecutions could be commenced in circumstances where it is apparent that the Medicare arrangements are being abused, but not necessarily in a deliberate or intentional manner. Prosecutions under this provision can be instituted within three years of the commission of the alleged offence. This period is necessary to ensure that the offence provision is effective. Similar periods apply elsewhere in Commonwealth legislation. By their nature, offences involving abuse of the Medicare scheme may not be detected until much later, for instance where accounts spanning a considerable period of time are received. Naturally, as we are dealing with a summary offence, penalties are much less than those provided for in the provision dealing with indictable offences.

I turn now to a new offence provision relating to persons who intentionally make a false or misleading statement which is capable of being used in connection with a claim for Medicare benefits. This is an indictable offence, and the onus will be on the prosecution to prove all elements of the offence beyond reasonable doubt. There is, of course, no time limit for prosecutions for indictable offences. Of course, the Director of Public Prosecutions will be responsible for deciding both whether a prosecution should be commenced and, if so, under which provision. I refer now to the proposed establishment of the Medicare participation review committees. They are to consider, following a successful prosection against a practitioner, whether the nature of the offence is such that the practitioner has so abused the position of trust conferred by Medicare that action affecting the practitioner's continuing participation in Medicare is warranted. Such action could entail counselling, reprimand, or disqualification from participating in the Medicare arrangements for a period up to five years.

A practitioner will be referred to a committee in all cases where an offence under the Health Insurance Act or a related Crimes Act offence is found proven. The committee is to consider, first, whether in fact any action is warranted. If it decides that action is not warranted, the matter will be immediately disposed of. Where the committee decides that some action may be warranted, the practitioner will be able to appear before the committee and be represented. There is provision for partial or full disqualification. A partial disqualification would mean that a service, or perhaps some services, when rendered by the practitioner would be ineligible for Medicare benefits. A committee could consider a partial disqualification appropriate where, for example, a practitioner has abused the system in respect of one item in the schedule or where full disqualification may seriously disadvantage a particular community.

The new arrangements provide for the issue of guidelines by the Minister to assist committees in the performance of their functions and ensure a consistent and even-handed approach. To this end, the guidelines are being prepared in consultation with the professional bodies. The guidelines will be subject to the normal parliamentary scrutiny and disallowance provisions. A right of appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal from decisions by the committee will exist. It is proposed that the committees comprise:
an independent chairperson with legal qualifications and considerable legal experience;
a person, nominated by the Minister, who is a member of the same professional as the practitioner before the committee; and
in cases involving medical practitioners, a person nominated by the Australian Medical Association; or
in cases involving non-medical practitioners, a nominee of the relevant professional association.

Relevant professional associations will be consulted when considering the appointment of chairpersons. As honourable senators can see, the committee will be an independent body which will be competent to determine, on the basis of evidence put before it, the matters referred to it.

This Bill also provides for the extension of statutory privilege for information obtained by medical counsellors during interviews with practitioners. As I said earlier, there has been a growing belief that confidential discussions with counsellors can lead to prosecution of practitioners. This amendment, which will cover both oral statements made in interviews and any written records of them, will protect the frank and free discussion so necessary if the objectives and benefits of counselling are to be achieved. I should perhaps point out that counselling is intended to be quite seperate from the investigation of persons suspected of committing offences, and that the extension of privilege will enhance, rather than detract from, the effective administration of Medicare.

Another aspect of the current legislation addressed by the Bill is that it is silent on who is to fill in the practitioner's account or receipt. It is clearly not appropriate for it to be the responsibility of patients. Hence the Bill amends the Health Insurance Act to provide that Medicare benefits are payable only where a practitioner or his staff includes the prescribed information on accounts. In summary, the information-to be prescribed by regulation-that will be necessary for the payment of Medicare benefits will be identification of the practitioner by name and either practice address or provider number; sufficient information to enable identification of the patient; and a description of the services provided, sufficient to identify the Medicare benefits schedule item, relating to those services. The new provisions will enable the Health Insurance Commission to have sufficient information to pay benefits. The less prescriptive requirements should meet with the approval of practitioners. It will be a matter for their own convenience if they continue to include item numbers with short descriptions of the services, as many do at present.

Honourable senators will note that the transitional arrangements include a provision enabling practitioners who are currently disqualified to apply to the Medicare participation review committee for a review of their disqualification terms. The committee will have the power to moderate such terms-it will not have power to increase them. Perhaps I should emphasise that the Bill was drafted before the recent report of the Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts into pathology was released. This report is now under consideration by the Government. It is possible therefore that further amendments of the offence provisions of the Health Insurance Act will need to be made following consideration of the report.

The measures I have outlined are the product of an extensive process of consultation with those professional associations whose members are most affected by them. The new arrangements have been endorsed by the Australian Medical Association, the Australian Optometrical Association and the Australian Dental Association. I believe the new scheme will provide a fair and effective framework for dealing with future cases of abuse and misuse of Medicare. As such they are a major advance on the present legislation which has done little to curb such abuse and misuse while at the same time antagonising the great majority of practitioners who are honourable and honest in the practice of their professions.

I turn now to clauses 57-66 of the Bill which relate to another significant Government initiative-the introduction of a national identification system using cards to be known as Australia Cards. As honourable senators will be aware, the system is an important part of the Government's planned reform of the Australian taxation system, as outlined in another place by the Treasurer in his statement of 19 September 1985. As the Treasurer indicated on that occasion, the Australia card is a weapon in combatting tax evasion and reducing welfare fraud in the community. Because of its acknowledged technical expertise, it is intended that the Health Insurance Commission, which administers Medicare and Medibank Private, will under substantive legislation to be brought forward next year be given responsibility for administering the Australia Card program. In the meantime, in order to enable the commission to undertake the planning work necessary for the establishment of the Australia Card program, an amendment is required to the Health Insurance Commission Act. That is the purpose of this part of the Health Legislation Amendment Bill. Various methods of authorisation were considered, but none of them provided a completely satisfactory legal framework within which the Commission could carry out its planning role. It was important, therefore, to prepare this enabling legislation in advance of the substantive legislation.

In his second reading speech in another place the Minister for Health emphasised that the proposed amendment to the Health Insurance Commission Act was to allow the Health Insurance Commission to do no more than the planning and development work necessary to enable the Government to prepare the legislation for the Australia Card programme. However, objections were raised to the amendment as introduced, apparently on the basis of a misunderstanding that the amendment might, by some means or other, permit the Commission to proceed with the implementation of the program. After discussions with the Australian Democrats and others, the Government agreed, in another place, to make a minor drafting change that would make it quite clear, as has been the Government's intention from the outset, that the Health Insurance Commission's responsibilities are strictly limited to the work necessary to enable the Government to bring forward the substantive legislation for the national identification system in 1986. The Bill before the Senate includes that change.

The Government intends that the Australia Card program become fully operation from July 1989. As a first step, it is planned that the issuing of Australia Cards begin in March 1987. Thus the Commission has a period of 16 months from now to undertake the necessary planning and following enactment of further substantive legislation, to prepare for card issue. As now will be abundantly clear to honourable senators, this enabling legislation allows for no more than planning work. In addition, as I mentioned earlier, a sunset clause has been included that means that the legislation will cease to have effect after December 1986 unless substantive legislation providing for the establishment and administration of the Australia Card program has been enacted before that date. In accordance with the specific provisions of the Health Insurance Commission Act, which require a system of cost apportionment to be applied when determining the assets and breakdown of expenditure by the Commission with respect to its various functions, other machinery changes to the Act have also been included. These will ensure that correct and proper financial accounting takes place within the organisation.

In support of this part of the Bill, let me simply say that the Government is convinced that the Australia Card program is crucial to ensure that everyone in the community contributes fairly towards the cost of providing Government services, and that no individuals or groups take more than their fair entitlement out of the community purse. Costs to the Government in 1985-86 on the Australia Card program will be confined to expenses which are absolutely necessary for the planning of the proposal by the HIC. Of course, this will require the Commission to spend sufficient funds so that thorough planning and research is carried out and that the purpose of planning to satisfy the needs of the Government and legitimate concerns of the public is properly achieved. The amount of expenditure in subsequent years is dependent upon the enactment and timing of substantive legislation providing for the Australia Card identification system. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I seek leave to make a personal explanation. I claim to have been misrepresented by the Australian media in connection with a report tabled this week.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have prepared a short statement relating to the report on the exposure draft in the Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee relating to a Bill of Rights, which report was extensively and falsely reported in the media. I released this statement to the whole of the media in an endeavour to have the matter corrected. No part of the media has taken any steps to do that so I will read the statement very briefly to the Senate. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Exposure Draft of the Senate Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee relating to suggested proposals for a Bill of Rights for Australia.

In view of the general misconceptions of the Australian media as to the purpose and intent of the Exposure Draft being a Report presented to the Senate on 5th November 1985, I desire to correct the following misconceptions. My Liberal colleagues on the Committee, Senators Hill and Puplick wish to be associated with this statement.

1. The Report is an Exposure Draft or Issues Paper containing no (repeat NO) recommendations that the Australian Parliament should adopt a Bill of Rights but analysing the arguments put before the Committee in some 168 submissions and evidence as to the purposes and possible content of a Bill of Rights if the Parliament sees fit to proceed to adopt one.

2. The Exposure Draft also considers the other bodies existing in the country dealing with human rights and considers the upgrading and development of personnel and powers of the Human Rights Commission as a possible alternative to the creation of a Bill of Rights.

It also assesses arguments that suggest that a Bill of Rights, as already discussed in the community, might face constitutional difficulties in its implementation of Australia's obligations under International Covenants.

3. The Exposure Draft supplies a great deal of factual material that should assist the development of dispassionate debate on this subject in the Parliament. It does not deal with the terms of the particular Bowen Bill, presently before the Parliament, but is designed to inform and hopefully elevate the public debate on the important and real issue of effective implementation of human rights obligations in Australia.

I add that a typical heading in the Press when the report came down was that of the Canberra Times, which stated: `Senate group plans toughter `Bill of rights'. Most of the reports were similar as though that was a recommendation of the Committee. That is not so. Furthermore, in the tabling statement by Senator Tate and in the speeches that I and other members of the Committee made when the report was brought down, the purpose of this draft was made abundantly clear. I say this by way of clarification because it is impossible to get the Australian media to recognise that they have made a mistake.
