Since the Budget, we have announced in our taxation package delivered on 19 September that the separate income test for rent assistance will be abolished. So young Australians in the age group of 18 to 20 will be eligible for a maximum benefit rate of $98.20 a week. That is an increase of $13 a week over the current rates available. As I indicated earlier, overall the aim of our youth policy known as Priority One is to pay allowances more on an age basis than according to what the individual is doing-whether that individual is unemployed or in education.

The third part of our youth package is to provide more places in higher education. That, of course, is to boost the supply of places to meet the extra demand generated by the youth scheme. There is no doubt that the higher youth benefits available will boost the demand for tertiary education. Between now and 1987 an additional 20,500 places will be provided in higher education institutions. The total cost to the Budget of these youth assistance initiatives is estimated at $70m in the current financial year, rising to $190m in 1986-87.

The second major priority area in the 1985-86 Budget is social welfare. From Thursday of next week pensions and benefits will be increased in line with the rise in the cost of living. There will be a $3.60 a week rise in the standard pension rate and the single unemployment benefit rate and a $6 a week increase in the married rate of pension. Further, the Budget has allocated $110m in the current financial year and $245m in a full financial year for increased social security benefits over and above the existing cost of living indexation arrangements. These major measures include a $3 a week extra rise for the single unemployed over 21 years of age who do not have dependants. That amount will be in addition to the $3.25 a week rise from this month due to cost of living increases. The unemployment benefit rate for this group of Australians will be $91.45. It is very important to note that when this Government came to office this was one of the groups most discriminated against in the community. The level of benefit that such people received was far below that received by single pensioners. It is noteworthy that early in 1983 single unemployed persons over the age of 21 without dependants received only $68.65 a week. Under this Government they will be receiving $91.45, which represents a very large rise in the benefit. Most importantly, the gap between the single unemployment benefit rate and the single rate of pension has been narrowed considerably. When this Government came to office, a single unemployed adult received $13.70 a week less than a single pensioner. As a result of the measures in this Budget, that gap will be reduced to $6.45 a week.

In respect of key poverty groups in Australia, from May next there will be a $10 a week increase in the income test free area for unemployment beneficiaries. The amount will rise from $20 to $30 a week. As I indicated earlier, there will be a new rental allowance for unemployed persons renting accommodation from private landlords of up to $10 a week. If I could just reiterate, since the Budget was handed down we have in fact abolished the separate income test for that rent allowance. From next week there will be a further $2 a week increase per child for the children of pensioners and beneficiaries. That amount will be increased to $16 a week. There will be a further $2 a week increase next week in the family income supplement per child. So this Government has introduced very important social welfare measures which highlight the Government's commitment to direct the benefits of Australia's high and continuing economic growth towards those Australians most in need-the unemployed and those households with dependent children which are receiving social welfare payments.

The 1985-86 Budget contains a number of redistributive measures which involve the redistribution of incomes to the neediest sections of the community. In addition to the increases in the social welfare payments, which I have outlined already, and a comprehensive education and training scheme for youth which we have called Priority One, other redistributive measures have been announced in the Budget. For instance, the threshold for payment of the one per cent Medicare levy has been increased. A single income family with two children now will not be required to pay the Medicare levy if their income is below $15,564. That is quite a significant income; it is by no means a bottom income in Australia. At the same time, the ceiling on the top amount of the levy which was payable will no longer apply. The one per cent levy previously applied to incomes of up to $75,000 with a ceiling of $750 per annum. The ceiling has now been abolished and people receiving very large incomes will be making a larger contribution for their health care.

This Budget contains some very important benefits for my State of South Australia. There will be continuing work on the long overdue $41m Commonwealth office centre in the central business district of Adelaide. There will be further expenditure and development of the Commonwealth office centre at Port Pirie in the mid-north of the State. That centre will be completed this financial year. Further assistance will be given to the motor vehicle industry. The Budget has provided $35m for the development of the Australian motor vehicle industry and, of course, South Australia, as a major producer of motor vehicles, will share in that allocation. A further revenue supplement will be made to Australian National, our national railway system. The allocation in this Budget of $72.5m is an improvement over the last financial year when an allocation of $87.9m was required to supplement the revenue flows of that organisation.

This Budget provides major expenditure for water improvement programs in South Australia. A total of $7.9m has been allocated for water improvements in my State. I am pleased to say that of that total $7.9m, $5.6m has been allocated for water filtration works to improve the quality of water both in Adelaide and in the regional areas of the State. An allocation of $1m has also been provided for flood mitigation works along the River Torrens through the metropolitan area of Adelaide. The Budget contains very important benefits for South Australia.

In the year ahead we are again expecting fast economic growth in Australia. During the three years of Labor Government, which will have ended at the conclusion of the current financial year, the economy will have grown by more in real terms than it did in the previous eight years under the Fraser-Howard Administration. There will have been more growth in Australia in three years under Labor than there was in eight years under Mr Fraser with Mr Howard as his Treasurer. A recent survey carried out by the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, an organisation of the world's leading industrialised developed countries based in Paris, predicts strong economic growth in Australia 1985-86. It bases its assessment on a strong growth in private consumer spending and very strong growth in private investment spending. These very important areas of the economy will provide the economic growth that is expected to take place in the current year. There will be a further decline in the level of unemployment in Australia. Of course, that level is still far too high; it is unacceptably high. However, I am certainly encouraged by the inroads that have been made into unemployment this year as a result of the policies of the Hawke Government.

The Budget itself forecasts that the pattern of Australia's economic growth will change during the current financial year. Last financial year over one-third of our growth in terms of gross domestic product actually was contributed by the public or government sector. In the current financial year it is estimated that less than one-sixth of Australia's economic growth will come from the public sector.

TALK.START.PARA: —One-sixth?

—Yes, Senator Cooney. That implies that five-sixths of the economic growth in Australia in the current year will be generated in the private sector and it is therefore making a major contribution to the economic recovery now occurring in Australia. The Budget predicts that there will be a 2 3/4 per cent increase in total employment levels in Australia during the current financial year. On my calculations that indicates that between 170,000 and 180,000 new employment positions will be generated in Australia during the current year. Unemployment is estimated to fall to between 7 1/2 per cent and 8 per cent as at the middle of next year. I must say that with the September 1985 unemployment rate of 8.1 per cent we are well on target to achieve a level of between 7 1/2 per cent and 8 per cent by the middle of next year. I am certainly very encouraged by that downward trend in unemployment which is now evident in the labour market.

SPEECH.PARA: The benefits of economic growth in Australia, I am pleased to say, are being shared in my State of South Australia. We are recording very strong economic growth there under the policies of the Hawke and Bannon governments. In the three months to September this year compared with the same three months of 1984 there was a 2.9 per cent growth in total employment numbers in South Australia. That is an average increase of 16,200 new jobs in South Australia compared with the same time last year. That increase in employment has been paralleled by a striking reduction in the total level of unemployment in South Australia in the same period. Between the three months to September 1984 and the three months to September this year the total number of persons unemployed in my State of South Australia fell by a very striking 8.5 per cent. That is a very large reduction indeed in total unemployment in South Australia as a result of the policies of the Bannon and Hawke governments.

I think that growth came, importantly, from growth in the motor vehicle industry. Registrations of new motor vehicles are very strong indeed. There was a 7.9 per cent growth in new motor vehicle registrations in South Australia in the last 12 months. In the retail sales area, consumer spending is very buoyant and in South Australia retail sales are well outdistancing cost rises. There was a rise of 11.5 per cent in retail sales in South Australia in the last 12 months, and that is a very welcome increase indeed. Of course, the bottom line to the performance of the economy, I believe, is the level of bankruptcies. That is the acid test of how well an economy is going. It is really important to note that in the 1984-85 financial year the total number of bankruptcies in South Australia fell 14.8 per cent-a striking reduction in a 12-month period compared with 1983-84.

Overall the 1985 Budget is a Budget for further growth but, of course, we in the Labor Party do not want growth for growth's sake; we want growth to enable us to create more jobs and to make more opportunities available to the needier sections of the community and to attack poverty in our country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Over the past five years the Australian people in three general elections have given a mandate to the Senate to be a House independent of two executive governments-the Fraser Government and the Hawke Government. The votes over that time have shown clearly that the Australian people want the Senate to be there as a control over the Executive. They want an independent Senate. I think that is probably the clearest single electoral message that has been delivered to this Parliament by the Australian people for some time. As a result of that the Senate is now very much a House where things happen. The Senate is in the news. I can recall that about a decade ago-about 1977-an opinion poll was taken which showed that the majority of the Australian people did not even know what the Senate was. Those days of the rubber stamp House, I believe, have disappeared and have disappeared forever.

SPEECH.PARA: It is for those reasons that I am speaking in this cognate debate on three Appropriation Bills, one of which is the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill. That Bill may sound boring and unimportant but in fact it is of vital importance. I speak in this debate because of the deep concern of the Australian Democrats over the tightening grip that the executive government is attempting to have over the business and actions of the Senate. Of course, this is a long, drawn out battle. It is not one that ever ends. It is one, I think, where battles are fought but the war itself goes on because it is the natural feeling of executive governments that they are always right and they do not like any curbing of their actions.

As honourable senators know, much provocative talk has been coming recently from Senator Peter Walsh on this matter and, because he is the Minister for Finance, we have to take seriously what he says in this regard. Senator Harradine, as honourable senators will know because he has circulated this letter, wrote to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and members of parliament last week pointing out a potential conflict of interest between the Senate and the Executive. He objected to what he called Senator Walsh's economic blackmail in refusing to guarantee that money would be available to set up a Senate select committee to look at Senator Harradine's in vitro fertilisation Bill. This is not the place to canvass that Bill one way or another other than to say that, like anything else that comes here, it should be susceptible to inspection by a committee. Certainly the Australian Democrats take with great seriousness this tendency by the Executive to fiddle with the Senate and to use what is, of course, the most obvious and easiest way of muzzling the Senate and that is by denying it the funds it needs to do its work effectively and properly on behalf of the Australian people.

In 1980, a new era in Australian politics began when the Democrats were given the balance of power in this chamber. We have repeatedly said, and I say now again, that we have never believed or acted as if we had the right to run the country, because we hold that crucial and historic position. Far from it. We have considered that philosophically and we have considered our position with great care. We have attempted to support and assist governments in their normal, reasonable patterns of legislation over that period. The record shows that only a very small amount of legislation has been amended by us and even smaller amounts have been stopped dead in their tracks by us. Where legislation has been stopped dead in its tracks our action has had the obvious support of the Australian people, and for the best of reasons. We do, however, perceive a mandate from the Australian people, which they have continued and confirmed in three subsequent elections, to moderate the extremism which has always been the absolute basis of the old fashioned former system of two-party government, leading as it does to confrontation, conflict and violent veering of policy. The Australian people rightly perceive how damaging the two-party system has been to them and now they have established firmly in their minds that principle which Senator Chipp has expressed as keeping the bastards honest.

We seven Democrats do not regard ourselves as the fount of wisdom. Far from it. However, we do perceive and have always perceived that the best tendency democracy can have in Australia is to give the Australian people a greater share in it and that is really what the committee system of the Senate is about. It is about giving to the people and to informed interest groups in a public setting the opportunity to bring facts and opinions to members of parliament of all parties who are meeting together in a non-confrontationist atmosphere. People can present a considered view of what is the best thing to do in a particular matter which has been referred to that committee. The Democrats, of course, would prefer to go further. We have pushed strongly for useful referenda and we have proposed a system of citizens initiative whereby a petition of half a million signatures would lead to annual referenda in which the people would decide on issues which are important to them, as occurs now in California, Washington State, Switzerland and a number of other advanced democracies.

A Senate committee basically is an authority of the Senate, made up of senators who sit as a group and take evidence in sessions generally open to the people and to the media, which seeks input from the people and from all interested parties and which seeks to establish the broad sweep of informed public opinion on an issue. That is its principal value. It is not politicians telling people what to do; it is politicians seeking guidance from the people on what needs to be done. I think that, with the educated, more informed electorate we have now, that is a good and healthy situation and one which, incidentally, is firmly established, as honourable senators will know, in the United States Senate, which I see in many respects as the path this Senate must take.

The committee system is valuable also because it does tend to break down that unfortunate, destructive and completely unprogressive system of party lines which has done this country so much damage and which is largely responsible for the appalling economic situation it is in now. We are basically a wealthy country. We have come to the pass we are at because of the ineptitude of the old parties and their inability to work together. Last year the Democrats took out some rather interesting figures. We found out that over 70 per cent of debate in the Senate was the Labor Party and the Liberal and National parties taking serves at each other. Barely a quarter of the time of the Senate was devoted to actual legislation and its proper concerns. That is a result of the two-party political system and that is why the Australian people do not like it and do not want it. The sooner we have a fair electoral system of multi-member constituencies in the House of Representatives where, indeed, the electoral wishes of the Australian people can be met and where they are truly represented by people they voted for instead of 49 per cent not being represented by people they voted for and the sooner we abandon that old fashioned, stupid, undemocratic system the better for this country and the people of this country. The sooner they realise that they should have input into the political process beyond what they have now and that they should be represented in both Houses according to the degree of their vote, the better it will be for Australia. As far as the Democrats are concerned, that cannot come too soon. We can see no argument against it other than the old parties trying to cling to their strange group collective mind attitudes which, to us, are absolutely obnoxious.

Briefly, the Senate committee system is a most valuable step forward in the process of democracy. It allows something more to the Australian people who can put in submissions to Senate committees, can come and speak before that committee and allow their words to be recorded in the evidence than this business of just a forelock-tugging vote every three years for one political party or another. I have often felt that this is rather like a small town where there are only two firms of lawyers and where some person said: `I am tired of undertaking my affairs, I will just go along to that firm of lawyers `A' and give it my power of attorney. It can sell my house, my business, trade-in my wife and do whatever it feels is necessary'. At the end of three years, that firm of lawyers having failed dismally, that person can say: `Look, you have done a pretty terrible job for me. I am going to go to the other firm of lawyers and let it try for three years'. At the end of another three years when that person is still not satisfied he can go back to the first firm of lawyers and say: `Look, you did a bad job too, but won't you please try this time. I will give you another chance'. The Government spends something like 40 per cent of our money. If it is good enough for us to worry about 60 per cent of it ourselves, it is good enough for us to be more concerned with the other 40 per cent.

The community considers that it is very important that there is some check and balance on the unfettered power of the Executive. It is for that reason that the Senate can now successfully claim to be the people's House, as indeed it is. The other place, with all respect to it, is a mere rubber stamp of the Executive. This is through no fault of its own. It is because of an antiquated, stupid and thoroughly unrepresentative system of electing members of parliament in single member electorates. As a member of the--

TALK.START.PARA: —Then why should it not deny Supply?
—This House?
—Yes.

—That is a very lengthy argument. Perhaps we will look at that matter on Monday. I do not know, Senator Durack. What does the honourable senator think? I would not like to take up time on that point at the moment because there are a few other points that I want to make that are more cogent to the Bill. As the Democrat representative on the Senate Standing Committee on Appropriations and Staffing, I did not scream, disallow or vote against the estimates for the Senate for the next year partly because that objection, on my part, would have served little purpose when the majority of the Committee were in favour of them, and partly because the Government did make some concessions to the Committee in important areas. I think that was a valuable and useful thing to have happened. There are two things going on in parallel: The Government, to some extent, is trying to co-operate with the Senate Appropriations and Staffing Committee and, on the other hand, it is speaking with a forked tongue. It has tried to creep up behind and destroy or influence the powers of that Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is worth making the point as to whether or not it is economic or reasonable for the Senate to be looking into matters through the committee system and what money is necessary for it. I will go back to my own experience briefly as a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Science, Technology and the Environment which looked into the problems of the effects of agent orange on Vietnam veterans. I found that a very intellectually demanding and challenging exercise because without expert advisers-I think any other members of the Committee who are in the chamber would agree with me-we would have made very little progress and we probably would have made some very false assumptions. I think it is necessary for the Senate committees if they are to do their work honestly and properly to have what advice is necessary to do that job properly. There is very little point in taking up the time of honourable senators, who are busy people, if indeed the Government cuts off the funds available to them to do that work properly. Plainly, such experts cost money. Is the money well spent? To determine that all we have got to do is to turn to the other principal means of inquiry available in a public sense. I refer, of course, to royal commissions.

We have had a great number of royal commissions recently. It is sinking into the Australian public just how enormously expensive they are for a variety of reasons. It is enormously more expensive, to a factor of perhaps 100 to one, of what it costs a Senate committee to do a similar type of work. I understand that the annual operations cost of one of the Senate standing committees is on the basis of approximately $10,000. If all costs attributable to the committee, such as staff, salaries, et cetera, are added, the average figure might turn out at something like $100,000. It is a fact that some Senate committee hearings do take a year. Some might take more than a year; it depends on the complexity of the matter concerned. But it is also a fact that they rarely take that length of time. A select committee dealing with a relatively simple matter can sometimes do it in a matter of weeks, certainly in six months. One might well say that the average cost of a Senate committee is about $50,000 a hearing. I think that is dangerously and culpably low. Senate committees, compared with committees in the United States of America where very efficient work is done, have virtually no staff at all. They are run on a literal shoestring. Honourable senators should remember that this is the Federal Parliament. This is in an area which is seeking to review matters of national policy.

It is absolutely inexcusable that Senate committees are called on to do the work that they do with an appallingly low staff situation. As I understand it, in the United States Senate, senators have a member of staff who deals only with their committee work. That is reasonable because committee work inevitably involves a huge mass of transcript, sometimes hundreds of thousands and millions of words of evidence. It is manifestly impossible for senators who have other work to do to go through every word of that evidence. Our staff members-the numbers are very small compared with those of the United States Senate-are over-burdened and that work cannot be done by them. Therefore we are tending, with the best will in the world, to get a situation where the report of that Senate committee is not as good as it should have been. That is not a criticism, far from it, of honourable senators because I have been in this position myself. It is simply that honourable senators can do only a certain number of things in a day, a week, a month or a year. It would be most desirable if each honourable senator had one staff member in the committee situation who could look at evidence and say `Okay, but there is this point and that point. We have not got that. It is not in the report and it should be', instead of leaving it to an overworked committee secretariat to do all these things.

We are looking at a cost of $50,000 to $100,000 for an effective Senate committee which is going to bring our recommendations in an important area of policy. By contrast, the Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union cost the Australian people $14,400,803-over $14m; the Royal Commission on Drug Trafficking cost $9,254,010; and the Royal Commission on Australia's Security and Intelligence Agencies cost $2,306,000. An interesting contrast is the Senate committee hearing with the Royal Commission on the Use and Effects of Chemical Agents on Australian Personnel in Vietnam. The committee came up with very much the same sorts of conclusions as the Royal Commission in that area. It is important to note that. The Royal Commission cost over $3.5m. The Royal Commission on British Nuclear Tests in Australia cost over $2m and the Royal Commission into the Australian Meat Industry cost over $1m. I think it is unconscionable that the Government should encourage a situation for purely political purposes, which is what it is doing-it is a matter of political clout of the Executive getting its way-and allow the Australian people to be let in for these huge costs which are met by the taxpayer which is an absolute Christmas for lawyers who get in there and get huge amounts of money as counsel in dealing with these matters when in fact in many cases those matters could be dealt with well by a conscientiously well-organised, reasonably financed Senate committee system, as is done in other countries. We know perfectly well-this is what Senator Walsh is on about-that the only reason the Government is prepared to perpetrate that deal on the Australian people, to cynically let them in for millions upon millions of dollars of expenditure unnecessarily, is that the Executive does not want the Senate to have any more power than it can help.

The point is that the Senate is a body of parliament independent of the executive government. The executive government does not control it. It is up to the Senate to decide for itself its own affairs and what money it should get within reasonable parameters and guidelines. That must be done responsibly. Is there any suggestion that one of the two Houses of parliament would use that opportunity to feather its nest, to increase grossly its expenditure? Is the Government making that sort of dishonourable accusation or taking that sort of attitude towards this House? If so, I ask it to withdraw those imputations and not bring forward any such suggestion at all.

It is rather interesting that there has been a 12.1 per cent increase in the estimates for the expenditure of the Department of the Senate for this year. In fact, the Senate Standing Committee on Appropriations and Staffing fought pretty much tooth and nail for every dollar we could reasonably get and for certain facilities for senators, such as computers, as honourable senators probably know. That 12.1 per cent increase may seem quite high, but when one bears in mind that the Government has increased the Parliament's size by 18.5 per cent, with an attendant extra strain on all its services, one can see that there has been a net drop in the Senate's money, not a net increase. That is a pretty bad situation and one we will have to look at very carefully next year. I do not see that members of this House can feel that we are undertaking our responsibilities to the people who elected us by allowing ourselves to be run around by the nose by the Executive Government and to be more or less cut back in a carping way over relatively small sums of money. As I said, when one compares those costs with those of royal commissions the case can be made quite abundantly that the Government has no right to economise in this area. It is not doing it to economise. It is doing it for political reasons-it wants to muzzle the Senate.

Has the Senate committee system been useful? I will briefly go over some of the select committees we have had recently and the issues which have been dealt with by them so that people can make their own judgments. A select committee was appointed on South West Tasmania to investigate the future demand and supply of electricity for South West Tasmania and other matters. Manifestly, South West Tasmania was one of the most important issues with which the Australian community had concerned itself for many years. On a Democrat initiative a Senate committee was appointed on private hospitals and nursing homes, their conduct, administration and ownership. That matter, again, had been crying out for investigation year after year and continually had been brought up by responsible members of the community who said that it needed to be investigated. It has been investigated as a result. There is the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare, one of whose references is the export of live sheep from Australia. An enormous amount of publicity and interest has been attracted by that Committee's hearings, and rightly so. It is the first time in this country's history that animal welfare, cruelty to animals, cruel experimentation and cruel practices in regard to animals have been studied. It is an indictment on us a nation that it is the first time it has happened. However, it has happened only because a Senate committee was able to take on the matter.

A committee was appointed to examine the classification and availability of video material in Australia. That committee, the Senate Select Committee on Video Material, as we know, has now collected a vast amount of material on what is probably one of the most controversial and important topics that has arisen in the community recently and one which has involved the Senate and the House of Representatives in fairly large amounts of debate. There is every piece of evidence, again, that the relatively small amounts of money spent on organising these committees and their results make the Senate committee system fairly valuable to the Australian people and something which should go on.

On that subject I go back a few years. I recall that during the Fraser Government's era, when Mr Viner was Minister for Industrial Relations, a set of industrial relations legislation was introduced which was grossly confrontative and very bad legislation. As a result of our vote in the Senate with the Labor Party that legislation was referred to one of the standing committees of the Senate. A fact which we, and most people, already knew and which the Executive then should have known was revealed, which was that the legislation was opposed not only by the labour unions but also by employers in Australia because they perceived clearly just how dangerous and damaging it would have been and how it would have led to massive industrial confrontation and crippling strikes. We would have been a much worse off and poorer country than we are now. As a result of the committee's findings-honourable senators should remember that it was an all-party committee-the Government quietly dropped the legislation, and very rightly so. I suggest that that again demonstrates the very considerable value to the Australian people of the Senate committee system. Again it bears very much on the Senate's ability and willingness to run its own affairs.

My primary purpose in speaking on this debate-one might say my bottom line-is to urge honourable senators, through you, Mr Deputy President, to support this House and its right to be a separate House which does things. For heaven's sake, honourable senators should not regard the political party or group as the thing which dominates or runs their lives in every possible way. That has been proved to be wrong and bad, not liked by the Australian people and an anachronism which will disappear. As honourable senators who have studied this matter will know, the party alliance system has become very blurred in the United States Senate for reasons which I have stated. United States senators will go right against their party policy when it comes to important matters concerning their own constituencies or merely matters which they think are important matters of conscience. That is the sort of House of review that a nation needs. It does not need a House of review such as the Senate used to be. I have studied past Hansards where the speeches made in the Senate were the same speeches made in the House of Representatives, almost word for word, and where the amendments that were brought up in the Senate were the same as those brought up in the House of Representatives. The Senate was purely a rubber stamp.

If we are to evolve along healthy progressive lines, and if Australia is to be a modern democracy, this House must have absolute control over its own expenditure, as I said, within reasonable guidelines. But those guidelines must see the review powers of the Senate as being of some reasonable, rational value to the Australian community. I suggest that the comparison I made of the Senate's costs with the costs of royal commissions is very telling in that regard and might induce the Government to do something about the situation, in other words, to be more liberal and take a realistic view.

The Democrats have discussed this matter and I speak with the authority of the members of our caucus. We believe that the Committee has not been unreasonable in its dealings with the Government over the matter of Senate funding-far from it. We believe that the Committee has tried to take a responsible and co-operative line in its dealings with the Government. However, as a general principle, the Democrats agree with the proposal which has been put to us by Estimates Committee A, which states quite categorically that the Senate should control its own expenditure. I believe that that proposal ought to be supported by the Senate. The Democrats and I are greatly worried by any suggestion, especially from any area in the Opposition, that the proposal ought to be watered down. I will deal with that matter a little more in a few minutes. We see Senator Walsh's present activities as being part of a Government attempt to muzzle the Senate by cutting back on its funding generally and its funding for committee work particularly. As I have said, that approach is completely unjustified, very wrong and goes very much against the normal tide of political events in this country that we should be following towards a better and more vocal democracy.

As a group the Democrats warn the Government that if it, and particularly Senator Walsh, persists in these attempts, we will take a very critical view of next year's Estimates and will move whatever amendments are necessary to create what, in our view, would provide the funds and facilities to the Senate that would allow it to do its work in the most effective way.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are saying that your whims will be indulged but nobody else's will.

—I am saying that this is an independent House of Parliament which ought to run its own affairs. Your Executive Government, as you know full well, does these things to the Senate for political reasons and allows the huge costs of royal commissions to conduct inquiries which could be conducted equally well here. That is what the Government is up to.
—Meanwhile the people leave them with no responsibility for raising revenue. We give $2,000 a day to Sydney QCs.

—Senator Walsh should not bring up such hypocritical stuff with me. He knows he is being hypocritical. Leaving Senator Walsh, I should like to have a bit of a serve at the other side too. I will not be happy if the Liberals move to water down the Committee's view on this matter. We do not want a pale, wishy washy resolution of it, surely. We want something which will be effective and which will assert the Senate's rights to do what it wants, within responsible guidelines. Perhaps there are some members of the Liberal Party who feel that maybe that Party will become the Government again at some time and they would prefer to keep the Senate under their control. By watering down this proposal sufficiently, they would do that. Maybe they are among those members of the Liberal Party who are now planning for a Fraser Liberal-National government after an election in November or December 1987.

SPEECH.PARA: Certainly, the Democrats believe that we are now seeing something of a rebirth of the Fraser phoenix from the ashes. I think that is abundantly clear. Those of us who were senators during the Fraser Government know only too well that Mr Fraser, as Prime Minister, adopted the principle that the best thing to do with the Democrats was to ignore the fact that we were here at all. He did not take our views into account and consult us. Of course, we were here and we increased our support steadily, while on the other hand the Fraser Government was abjectly defeated after a double dissolution, one of the issues of which was a Bill we stopped. We watch with great interest, purely as outside observers-we would not seek to interfere in Liberal Party matters; far from it-the tendencies within the Liberal Party. Mr Fraser is very much more in the news. I hear from the Melbourne business establishment that there could be some moves among the supporters of the Liberal Party for Malcolm Fraser to return.

A return to Fraserism would make it all the more essential that the Senate take the sensible, responsible view of its own rights and positions and assert that view strongly. The time to do that is now. I suggest that the Senate take up this proposal from Estimates Committee A. I know that other senators will discuss this matter during the debate, and it is very important. It is something which concerns every Australian ultimately. Although it may seem to many Australians when they listen to us in the Senate that a lot of the time what we do is pretty fuzzy, and I can understand that, eventually when a Bill is passed it becomes law that is imposed on all Australians. Therefore the powers of the Senate, as in the environment legislation case I mentioned earlier, are crucial. Because of that, I hope other senators will take part in this debate. I hope they will support the Australian Democrats' view that anything we can do within responsible guidelines to assert the authority, independence and financial independence of the Senate is very well justified.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: -The Senate is dealing cognately with three Bills which deal with total appropriation this year by the Government of about $69,000m. The important part of the estimates of expenditure that are presented is the bottom line, which shows that we will spend $5 billion more this year than we will take in in income. I believe that $5 billion is a very conservative estimate. Given the policies this Government is following, that amount will blow out, and it will probably blow out to $6 billion or $7 billion. There is a belief in Australia that deficits do not matter, but running a country is exactly the same as running a business or a family household. One has to earn the money to pay one's debts. Somehow or other, under the big spenders of the Australian Labor Party, the belief has been sold year after year, so that it is now entrenched in Australian folklore, that we can spend up big, it does not matter, there will never be a day of judgment. It did not matter in the past when Australia had a lot of money in the bank after good Liberal administration; but after three years of the incompetence of those opposite we do not have any money in the bank and money has to be found somewhere.

SPEECH.PARA: Under the brilliance of the boy Treasurer, Mr Keating, we are spending $13m a day more than is coming in. That is roughly $100m a week. The only good thing that can be said about this 1985-86 Budget is that the projected deficit is a little lower than it was last year. Last year, according to the Treasury documents, the actual figure was $6,700m. The year before that, though, we had the record for Australia of $8 billion. I refer to the point that has often been made by Senator Walsh, and it was made this morning by Senator Maguire. I do not know whether it is done out of dishonesty or stupidity, but they talk about the losses--

TALK.START.PARA: —Both.

—It might be both, as Senator Messner says. The biggest loss under the Fraser Government was $4.4 billion. That figure happens to be on page 396 of one of the documents brought down this year by Treasurer Keating. The year before that, the loss was $0.5 billion. The average loss for the seven Fraser years was around $2.5 billion, but in the three years of the Hawke socialist Government we have seen losses of $8 billion, $6.7 billion, and now, hopefully, we will have a loss of only $5 billion.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian public and the children of the Australian public have to pay off these debts. The very great problem we face is that the members of the Australian public do not realise that those debts are hanging like lead weights around their necks. They do not realise that this Government has been borrowing to the hilt overseas to pay for the debts it has run up, and that is the real killer. We now owe a huge amount of money to overseas bankers and to overseas institutions. We have simply lived beyond our means. We have spent money we do not have. We have not spent that money on building new Snowy Mountains hydro-electricity schemes or in developing any income-producing assets. We have spent that money on soft living. We have met our daily living expenses by borrowing. The Australian public does not realise this and it does not realise the extent of this $68 billion debt that hangs around our necks.

Mr Deputy President, do you realise that only 15 years ago Australia owed $3.5 billion? Today, it owes $68 billion. That debt has risen by 43 per cent since this Government came to power. Roughly one-third of all our export earnings this year will go on paying the interest alone on overseas borrowings. On the projections the Department of the Treasury has made, working on an exchange rate of 70c to the United States dollar, it has been estimated that by the end of this financial year 43 per cent of our export earnings will be going just to pay interest-not to paying off the capital and not to paying off the borrowing-but just to pay the interest on what we have borrowed.

As Senator Messner so eloquently said earlier this morning, the exchange rate is collapsing and although we are now paying one-third of our export earnings in interest and it is projected that we will be paying 43 per cent by the end of this financial year, we could be looking at a figure in excess of 50 per cent of all our export earnings going to pay off the profligacy of the Labor Party. That leads me to the crux of the matter. It is not so much the amount of money we have borrowed as our ability to repay it that is the real killer. Under the policies of this Government, and partly due to the overseas markets, our ability to repay is poor, and it is declining day by day. We have borrowed money for soft living and our ability to pay it off and to service it, to pay the interest on it, is diminishing day by day. How has all this come about? I guess that, historically, the true origins go right back to the Whitlam years when, like a bunch of kids getting into a sweet shop, members of that Government took off on a wild spending spree. They lacked the ability to control the unions. We had the notorious blowout of over 10 years ago--

TALK.START.PARA: —Who was President of the trade union movement then?

—It was a fellow called Mr Hawke. I was just coming to the point of quoting what Mr Hawke's economically responsible views were. In August 1974, when Mr Hawke was President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, after an approach had been made to him to moderate his wage claims for his greedy unions, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: We know inflation is at 16 per cent and we believe it's quite likely to reach 20 per cent in the next two quarters. But we will not indulge in a trade-off in wages for some conjectural reduction in inflation.

The legacy of inflation took unemployment figures from the 1.8 per cent that the Australian community had enjoyed under a succession of Liberal-National Party governments preceding the Hawke regime, up to the 9 to 9 1/2 per cent levels that we have seen since. The level has now fallen to about 8.8 per cent. Under the Fraser Government we had seven years of responsible policies-gradually winding back the debt position of Australia and gradually improving the competitiveness of Australian industry. That was blown out by the wild men of the Hawke Government because the Cabinet and the Caucus of the Hawke Government still contain the big spenders. They are unable to learn the lessons of history. They are unable to learn the history of all Labor administrations in Australia since Federation; that is, they are big spending, big borrowing, irresponsible governments in an economic sense. This Government is the biggest borrowing and the biggest spending government in Australia's peacetime history.

I return to the point that there are chilling portents for Australia in the diminished ability we have to service the great debts that this Government has dumped upon the Australian people and the Australian economy. Despite what those on the other side say, the internal economy is not in good shape. The strategy of the Government has been to run a series of expansionist Budgets but, unfortunately, the rest of the world has no confidence in them. That is the real reason the exchange rate now is so disastrous. It is because the informed community overseas does not value the Australian dollar at much more than about US60c to US65c. I believe, regret- tably, that the dollar will go down even lower. To try to solve the problem the Government has had to follow a tight monetary policy. Australia now has the highest real interest rates since the Depression. The real interest rate, of course, is the difference between the inflation rate and the nominal rate that is charged. With the reduction in the inflation rate that has taken place through diminished economic activity, we now have these huge real interest rates that make it very difficult, if not impossible, to stay in business, let alone expand, and make it very difficult for the Australian taxpayer to buy a house. The situation will get worse because, as the dollar goes lower and lower, the Government will tighten the screws, as its socialist comrades have done in New Zealand, increasing interest rates as the Australian dollar goes down to lower and lower levels. What went wrong? Firstly, Labor overspent wildly. Secondly, the Government failed to make Australia competitive by freeing up the labour market and doing something to get down the extraordinarily high costs of labour. The third thing the Government did wrong was to seek a soft and easy option by floating the dollar through a covert devaluation. The fourth thing the Government did wrong was to provide no incentive at all to business, and I use the word `incentive' in its broadest sense.

I have dealt with the overspending side of the Government's strategy-the $5 billion deficit and the average $6.5 billion deficit which it has been running since it got into power. The second point I raise is Australia's competitiveness in the manufacturing industry and the need to control labour costs. The cost of employing labour in Australia today is probably the highest in the world. We have very high wages, but it is not the wages that pose the real problem; it is all the add-ons that follow-workers compensation, holidays, statutory holidays, sick days and the superannuation that is now coming in through the unions, covertly, which is a deferred payment. The add-on cost to employing labour today would approach 50 per cent of the nominal weekly pay. Quite simply, we cannot afford it. We have to free it up.

What we have to do in this country is not legislate for and support more and more union power, as this Government is committed to doing, but unleash the great human resources in Australia. An enormous number of people in Australia are prepared to work, and work efficiently, if only they can get to the work place. If they can get to a situation in which they are happy to work under terms which suit them and which, at the same time, suit an employer. What we have in Australia at present is a domination of the economy by the big unions. The big unions are running a monopoly on the supply of labour. This fits in very well with the doctrine of the Government, because its holy trinity is that we need big government, big business and big unions but we do not need small entrepreneurs, small business people and, above all, individuals because they just clutter up the scene which is dominated by the big three. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Walsh) agreed to:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today I intend to raise a matter which is a Queensland State Government responsibility, not a Commonwealth one. I consider, as a senator for Queensland, that it would be remiss of me not to advise honourable senators and those listening to the broadcast of a disgraceful incident in a government school in Queensland last week. The fact that a vast amount of Commonwealth Government money finds its way to Queensland schools gives me an additional reason to air this matter. Government schools in Queensland, normally referred to as State schools, are established and administered under the provisions of the State Education Act and the regulations to that Act. The matter which I wish to raise today is concerned with the wearing of school uniforms. Nowhere in the Act is there any provision to compel students to be clothed in any special way. Despite the lack of compulsion, school uniforms are worn by a great number of students in Queensland's State schools, both primary and secondary.

SPEECH.PARA: The wearing of a school uniform is not universally accepted by parents and students in Queensland. Nevertheless, there are concerted moves in many Queensland State schools to force students to wear uniforms even though principals and teachers do not have any legal power to enforce their own policy of a uniformed school. Detentions and other punishments are not unknown for those students who arrive at school without a uniform or with their uniform incomplete. A form of punishment which most recently has been used has been the exclusion of students from school photographs and extra-curricula activities. This authoritarian behaviour continues despite its complete illegality. I should indicate that it is not only my interpretation of the State Education Act and its regulations that students in Queensland's State schools may not be compelled to wear uniforms. For example, the State Minister for Education, in a letter to me in March this year, stated:
There is no legal requirement that students who attend State schools should wear school uniform.

In spite of this statement, a compulsion to wear uniforms is condoned, if not encouraged, by the State Minister for Education. For example, in last Saturday's Courier-Mail, Mr Powell was reported to have said:
If the school has a uniform it is expected that children will wear it.
That statement is in line with comments that Mr Powell has made to me by way of correspondence even though he recognises that there is no legal requirement.

Let me at this stage refer to a particular incident which occurred in a Queensland State school. After I made some comments on this matter earlier this week I received numerous telephone calls which indicated that the incident to which I am about to refer was by no means an isolated event. Basically, the facts are that a teenage girl was not wearing the full school uniform, had a note from her mother outlining the reason for her daughter's mode of dress that day and was forced to strip and don an old second-hand uniform. The report in last Saturday's Courier Mail records the incident in detail and I therefore intend to read it to the Senate. The article, headed `Mothballs in ``filthy'' uniform started rash, mother claims', states:
An epileptic schoolgirl said yesterday she was forced to strip to her underwear in an empty classroom on Thursday because she was not wearing full school uniform.

Cherrie Grant, 14, a student of Kedron High School, said she was also forced to put on an outsized, `filthy, smelly', used uniform by a female teacher which caused an inflamed rash over the top of her body.

Cherrie's mother, Mrs Cathy Platt, of Wavell Heights, said doctors who had examined her daughter at Royal Brisbane Hospital yesterday told her mothballs and bacteria in the old uniform had probably caused the rash.
She said Cherrie had worn a new white T-shirt with her sports skirt to school on Thursday because she had recently outgrown her school T-shirt.
She had written a covering note to explain this to teachers.
According to Cherrie, the teacher, Miss Anne Stoodley, had ignored the note and insisted Cherrie take off her clothes in an empty classroom and put on an old second-hand uniform.
Cherrie's request to change in the girl's lavatory was refused, she said.
Cherrie said she felt embarrassed and humiliated all day by her appearance in the outsized tunic and had hidden during breaks to avoid being seen.
Mrs Platt, who is a nurse, said she arrived home on Thursday afternoon to find Cherrie slumped in the bathroom, still wearing the old uniform.
`I was very worried that she may have had a fit and swallowed her tongue. She was ill and incoherent and by the next morning had broken out in a red rash', she said.
`Cherrie has never had any problems at the school and gets good grades. The T-shirt she was wearing was new and plain white.
`She was forced to wear this filthy, smelly one around all day and all the way home.'

Miss Stoodley said last night that she has instructed a student who was not properly attired to change into a school uniform. The uniform was supplied from a stock of spare uniforms held for that purpose.
Miss Stoodley said she had acted in accordance with the school policies in the matter.
The school's acting principal, Mr Chas Walker, yesterday defended Miss Stoodley and said he tried to ensure all students were reasonably dressed and tidy.
He said the school's Parents and Citizens group fully supported his attitude to uniforms.
`The school and the students' future jobs depend on the image of the students. I expect teachers to have reasonable control,' he said. He said Cherrie Grant was not a `troublemaker' at the school.
The Education Minister, Mr Powell, confirmed last night that school uniforms had never been compulsory in Queensland.
`But if the school has a uniform it is expected that children will wear it,' he said.
He said Mrs Platt's claims would be investigated if a formal complaint was received in writing.

So there we have it. This student had a note from her mother which was ignored; she was ordered to strip to her underwear by a female teacher; then she was forced to put on an ill-fitting, secondhand uniform which was filthy and smelly. The girl's mother deserves to be commended for taking the matter to the newspaper. To have made a formal complaint would have resulted in the sort of whitewash that inevitably follows such complaints in Queensland. The student herself is to be commended for allowing the story to be made public. Hopefully, her actions may prevent a similar incident from occurring to another student in future.

On the other hand, the actions of the teacher and the acting principal who supported the action are to be condemned. But the real villain in the piece is the Minister for Education. He should have known that a parents and citizens association does not have the authority to enforce the wearing of uniforms. Individual P and Cs may make a decision to have a school uniform but their decision can in no way be binding on students. Mr Powell says that if a school has a uniform it is expected that children will wear it. What would he do if they do not comply-suspend them or gaol them? The truth is that Mr Powell can expect what he likes but neither he nor the teachers he directs have any power to enforce their school uniform expectations.

In conclusion, I support a comment made by Mrs Beverley Galtos, the Secretary of the Queensland Council of Parents and Citizens Associations. Earlier this week she said that Mr Powell should issue a stern instruction to principals who punished students who did not conform. One would hope that a little tolerance for opposing points of view would be a personal quality of a Minister for Education. If that quality does exist, he should show some leadership and issue the type of instructions suggested by Mrs Galtos.

Senator B. Kilgariff
7 November 1985
RESPONSE TO SENATOR WALSH'S ANSWER TO SENATOR BOLKUS'S QUESTION IN THE SENATE ON 6 NOVEMBER 1985

(iii) Guarantees and Contingent liabilities on other projects (Yulara/Sheratons).

(b) Look at page 4 and 5 of the statements-the majority of the assumptions upon which the commitment on Yulara and the Sheratons were based involved the Federal Government honouring its own commitments-airports at Darwin and Alice, facilities at Kakadu and Uluru, and some control (the Commonwealth's responsibility) over real interest rates.

(c) The proposals in the statement, of Ian Tuxworth attached, to remedy these problems are already yielding success. The measures announced in the 1985 N.T. (d) The panel of independent advisors has been working closely with the special N.T. Government task force called the Tourist Infrastructure Advisory Group and progress is solid with real optimism that a range of initiatives under discussion will dramatically reduce the N.T. Governments exposure.

(g) The N.T. has had considerable support from the financial and banking communities. Support for the N.T. is high because they trust the N.T. to sort out its own problems; if they have any concerns at all they are that Senator Walsh, in his moments of pain and madness, and his Labor colleagues are determined to undermine the N.T.'s efforts in this regard.

Poll showed 76% of Australian's supporting, and designed by Senator Walsh maliciously to denigrate the Northern Territory's financial reputation.

(v) RE: The Uluru campaign advertising costs. It would cost a State the same or lesser amount to run the same campaign and it is intellectually dishonest to draw comparisons based on per capita calculations. It costs the N.T. more to run a campaign because of the inordinately high cost of airfares (which is a direct of morally bankrupt Commonwealth policy)-but then the Commonwealth should know this because it spent $400,000 or more on a party at Ayers Rock which less than a quarter of all Australians supported and which the Prime Minister and most of his senior Ministers were too embarrassed to attend. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to outline some of the ruses used by some people in the Public Service who I believe want to turn freedom of information into freedom from information. In the last annual report on the Freedom of Information Act, covering the financial year 1983-84, the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) wrote:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . while some problems in administration have been identified, the Act is working well and achieving its stated purpose of extending as far as possible the right of the Australian community for access to information in the possession of the Australian Government.

I would like to deal with some of these problems in administration. It is clear from a reading of the annual report that the figures given for the cost of freedom of information are highly inflated not to say spurious, and that we have no clear idea of where our money is being spent. At page 126 of the report it is revealed that the figure of 88 per cent used for on-costs is based on an extract from a Public Service Board publication. The footnote on that page points out that if a figure of 60 per cent were used-that is the more usual figure-the assessed cost of freedom of information legislation would be reduced from $17m to under $14.5m. So around 15 per cent of the stated cost has been arrived at just on the advice of the Public Service Board and the Department of Finance.

Before we can calculate the on-costs, however, we need to know the staff years spent on freedom of information matters. The 1983-84 annual report tells us that agencies were required to submit estimates of this time. At page 124 of the report it goes on to say:
No account was sought for any cost which an agency was able to absorb by greater use of existing resources, or a minor reallocation of official duties to meet FOI responsibilities.

We are in fact being given figures that need not necessarily correspond with what actually happened in practice. Further, in paragraph 6.6.8 on page 136 of the annual report, we find the following comments about agencies:
. . . they were not requested to provide, and therefore did not provide, separate details of the costs of all review and appeal procedures under the Act.

Obviously, internal review procedures will cost a lot more, because more senior officers are involved. What does the record show about internal review? I think this is very significant. Of 501 requests for internal review in 1983-84, 222-nearly half-resulted in some concession by agencies to the applicants. We need to know the costs of these wrong decisions, and I ask the Government to give us this information. We need to know what agencies are doing to ensure that the officers who first deal with requests actually understand the spirit of the legislation. These officers should seek to make information available wherever possible instead of looking for costly excuses for not doing so.

The next step up from the internal review procedure is an appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. There were 203 such appeals during 1983-84 plus 50 carried over from the previous year. In 46 cases the agency withdrew from the case by conceding the material. In a further six cases the agency decision was set aside or varied by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. That means that there were 52 cases of clear errors. What other errors in treating requests were made by people who might have been more timorous in not following through the full appeals procedure? This is where a lot of the cost to the community comes from. In fact, this is where the real money that we are paying for the freedom of information is coming from-in the time of very senior personnel being involved in the review procedures because the original personnel were not sufficiently trained to understand or because there is some policy at a high level of not providing the information. Huge savings can surely be achieved in the operation of the Freedom of Information Act through departments and other bodies not clinging irrationally to material. I ask everyone here: Is this open government?

I draw the Senate's attention to a letter I received from the Public Interest Advocacy Centre in Sydney pointing out an alarming trend towards secrecy. The Public Interest Advocacy Centre said that some departments were refusing to disclose documents until the applicants actually found themselves on the doorstep of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. By that time the applicants had already incurred substantial costs and worry and the Department had spent a good deal of time on the particular case and had probably briefed legal counsel at substantial public expense. This game of bluff is, I believe, disgraceful when so many departments complain of being underresourced. With that letter, which came to me in May, the Public Interest Advocacy Centre enclosed a copy of a letter sent to the former Ombudsman complaining about the practice of pushing the public to the law or to appeal procedures. It gives specific examples. I seek leave to have that second letter incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
3rd May 1985
Prof. Jack Richardson
Commonwealth Ombudsman,
Prudential Building,
London Circuit,
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Professor,
Re: Commonwealth Departments' Administration of Freedom of Information Act

As you are intimately aware, the Public Interest Advocacy Centre has for some time been actively involved in conducting litigation on behalf of its clients under the Commonwealth Freedom of Information Act. We have developed a significant expertise in the area and have prepared publications and conducted seminars to assist both bureaucrats and members of the community to understand the benefits and operation of the legislation.

It is becoming too clear in the conduct of our litigation that the attitudes adopted by a range of Commonwealth agencies to applications for documents under the Act are misguided and, to say the least, quite inconsistent with the spirit of the legislation.

Whilst we can relate some examples, one of which we request you to formally investigate, we suggest these cases are evidence of a wider practice being adopted by agencies whereby they ultimately grant requests for documents, but not until proceedings have been commenced in the Administrative Appeals Tribunal seeking review of decisions refusing to disclose documents. Such a practice is, in our view, highly undesirable and only goes to maximise the costs of administering the legislation. It also seriously penalises applicants who are forced to either appeal against agencies' refusals to disclose documents or forego their rights to documents which may not, in law, be exempt under the Act, although agencies initially claim that they are.

We acted in a matter on behalf of Ms Betty Hounslow, a community worker with the Marrickville Legal Centre, who sought access to three documents from the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. The conduct of that Department in non-compliance with the technical requirements of the legislation is a cause for some concern. The Department failed to comply with the deadlines imposed by the Act and once our client had appealed to the AAT, it failed to comply with its obligations under the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act in providing S.37 statements within the required or indeed a reasonable period until the Tribunal made a direction requiring it to do so. Those are matters of perhaps minor concern compared with our complaint about the practice which we believe is of the greatest concern to the proper administration of the FOI legislation and the Department itself.

As it turned out, at the hearing before the AAT on 10th April, 1985, the Department advised that it would provide to our client all of the documents sought by her, other than those parts of some 12 pages out of a total 226 pages. Our client had already conceded at a Directions Hearing on 31st January that she no longer sought access to the documents referred to in Clauses 17, 18 and 19 of the affidavit of Mr Ian Simmington of 15th January 1985, a copy of which we attach, marked ``A'' for your attention.

Without canvassing in great detail the facts leading up to the hearing, until the 4th of April 1985, we were led to believe that the Department persisted in its refusal to disclose either of the two documents the subject of the application to the Trtibunal for review, namely the ``Grant of Resident Status Handbook-Review of Family Migration Policy-Admission of Spouses and Fiancees'' (the ``Spouse Paper'') and the ``Review of Australian Procedures for Determining Refugee Status'' (the ``DORS Review'').

On the 4th of April 1985, we were advised by the Australian Government Solicitor who was then acting in the matter, that the Department had agreed to concede much of the two documents although it was unclear precisely what remained in issue. On the morning of the 10th of April 1985, having briefed Counsel and having summonsed a witness at considerable expense to our client, the Department advised that it was prepared to concede all of the two documents but for parts of pages referred to in clause 17-19 in the said affidavit of Mr Simmington along with some six other pages in respect of which it claimed, for the first time, an exemption under s.33 of the Freedom of Information Act. On the undertaking by Counsel for the Department that evidence was available to satisfy the exemption under s.33 (2), our client instructed us to withdraw her application in respect to those six pages.

Whilst that satisfactorily disposes of the matter, insofar as our client has now been promised access to the great bulk of the documents she sought, the problem remains that she was promised access only after some ten months after her initial request and after having incurred considerable expense in doing so. In addition, the expense and time consumed by this legal aid office, which we and our clients consider to be of considerable value, as well as the time expended by a barrister whom we instructed, was significant. Of even greater concern are the resources devoted by the Department to resisting disclosing these documents until the date of the hearing. In our view the Department's conduct is particularly deserving of criticism in view of the fact that one of its own legal officers, Mr Russel Patrick, indicated in a Minute to his superiors in the Department that the document was largely innocuous and the claim for exemption was unlikely to succeed for the most part. We enclose a copy of this Minute which was provided with the ``T'' documents dated 21st December 1984, to which is attached the comment from one of Mr Patrick's senior officers whom we understand was the decisionmaker on the internal review decision, Mr Simmington, where it is said somewhat glibly: ``this is not legal judgment!''.

We are aware of no change in law or practices affecting the Department which resulted in its complete turn around in respect to this request. We submit that the proceedings could have been avoided entirely had a reasonable consideration been given to the request in the first instance or at least on internal review. The absence of such reasonable consideration resulted in enormous expense not only to the parties but also to the AAT as a result of the Tribunal having to unnecessarily preside over what became, at the last minute, a non-issue.

Whilst our client is concerned personally at the expense which she has incurred to date in the proceedings and which includes the cost of bringing Mr Patrick to Sydney from Canberra to appear as our witness both she and we are gravely concerned that this practice is common to Commonwealth Departments in their reactions to FOI requests.

We are aware personally of two other AAT matters, Michael Rae v the Department of Arts, Heritage and Environment and Lianos v the Department of Social Security in which we were personally involved where similar ``settlements'' occurred on the ``door step'' of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. In the former case, the Department conceded that all of the documents in issue should be disclosed the day before the hearing was to take place. In the latter case, the bulk of the documents in issue were provided only a day or so prior to the hearing. We are also aware of a matter which has received public attention, McGregor v Department of Defence where we understand from media reports that that Department agreed to disclose all of the documents only just prior to the date for hearing before the AAT.
This suggests to us a pattern of behaviour on the part of Departments which is insidious.

The practice would appear to be even more widespread according to the Freedom of Information Act Annual Report 1983-84, in which 46 of 253 applications made to the AAT are described as ``withdrawn after agencies conceded''.

In our submission, this behaviour on the part of agencies resembles the conduct of commercial insurance companies which frequently seek to ``call plaintiffs' bluffs'' by forcing them to pursue their litigation until the commencement of the hearing before offering to settle matters. The effect of such conduct is to effectively discourage a great many litigants from proceeding with their claims for financial and/or emotional reasons. Precisely the same effect is achieved by Departments behaving in this fashion in respect to FOI requests. The inappropriateness of departments employing such delay tactics to resist disclosure of documents in this jurisdiction is self-evident.

In our respectful submission, it is appropriate for your Office to conduct an investigation as to the extent of this practice with a view to persuading agencies to discontinue it. We by no means suggest that agencies should be discouraged from providing maximum access to documents where appropriate. However, if agencies ultimately decide to provide access to documents only after applications to the AAT have been lodged, there is nothing to prevent them from providing access when the initial request is made or on internal review. The costs to the public and the applicant can thereby readily be minimised. Implicit in the conduct of the Departments in the abovementioned matters is a clear failure to properly consider requests for documents initially and on internal review in accordance with the Act.

To bring about greater compliance with the legislation as suggested, ought to, in our view, significantly reduce the costs to the Commonwealth for its administration. We note such costs were some $17 million for the year 1983/84. Your attention is drawn to chapter 6.6 ``Details of Costs Incurred in the FOI Annual Report'' which clearly demonstrates the enormous additional costs burden arising from applications for documents which proceed on review to the AAT.

We would be happy to provide any further information or assist in your investigation in any manner which you may consider appropriate. We look forward to hearing from you at the earliest opportunity regarding your reactions to firstly, our clients complaint against the Department of Immigration and secondly, our proposal that you conduct a wider investigation as outlined above.
Yours sincerely,
Public Interest Advocacy Centre
per: Mark Lynch
Solicitor
Encl.
c.c. Auditor-General
Registrar, Administrative Appeals Tribunal

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I think I have established conclusively that when a Senate committee examines the Freedom of Information Act after the three years of operation as is provided for in that Act, it will have a considerable amount of work to do. This work will be necessary to disentangle the financial web and the mystique that has been set up around freedom of information. When we look at the total number of staff years needed to administer the freedom of information legislation in 1983-84 we see on page 340 of the last annual report that the average all-round cost of each staff year was $50,000. By back calculation to clear the on-costs component, we can see that the average salary for each staff year was $27,000. Once again we have clear evidence that senior officers are being dragged in far too often.

SPEECH.PARA: Some departments had really noticeable problems. Both the National Capital Development Commission and the former Department of Territories and Local Government had staff costs much higher than the average figures. For instance, the Attorney-General's Department and the Department of Territories and Local Government spent virtually the same number of staff years, yet the Attorney-General's Department had salary costs $130,000 lower than those of the Department of Territories and Local Government. I believe that this must show some problem of administration. Otherwise, what does it show? Maybe the Government can answer us.

Agencies, I believe, should be made to justify their performance publicly. That is part of what open government is about. Not all time spent on freedom of information matters is spent on the processing of requests. Allowing for that, and also for the variation in complexity of requests, I believe that an interesting measure of the performance of each department is given by the average cost per request. Departments such as Veterans' Affairs which apparently have a genuine freedom of information outlook and handle many requests to look at individual files have required $213 per request and, mind you, that includes the artificially inflated on-cost factor of 88 per cent proposed by the Finance Department and the Public Service Board. However, other departments obviously believe much more in secrecy. The Commissioner of Taxation and the Departments of Social Security, Defence and Immigration and Ethnic Affairs averaged around $1,000 per request or less. These were next in cost. At the other end of the scale quite a few agencies-I could name them but they would probably recognise themselves-came in at over $5,000 per request. Even allowing for vexatious and voluminous requests, that is an enormous disparity over the whole output of a given department. I believe that either some of these estimates are inaccurate or there are serious structural and attitudinal problems that have to be sorted out within those departments.

These problems will not be tackled by increasing fees and generally discouraging people from making requests.
