The Opposition does not know what it is talking about when it says that some secret deal is going on between the ACTU and the Labor Government. It does not understand that we have a tripartite situation. I know what employers would say to the Opposition if they were asked whether they would rather have an accord and wage indexation or go back to the good old days of the concrete jungle when one had to fight for the best one could get. They would say that they want the accord. That is why they are working so well together with the ACTU and the Government. I make those few remarks to let the people of Australia know about the cons on the other side of this House, who are trying to destroy something that has been built up and which those opposite know in their own minds they could not build up by negotiation or by dialogue with the ACTU. As other senators have mentioned today, the only thing they achieved over that period was the dismantling of the wage indexation system back in the early 1980s. We know what happened during that period. As honourable senators on this side have said, there was a situation where the strongest got the best and the weakest got nothing. Those opposite want to go back to that situation, but it will not be accepted by the trade union movement and it will not be accepted by the community. I suggest to Senator Collard and his colleagues who are pushing this bandwagon that they should go back and talk to the people who count-the people of New South Wales and the people of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Zakharov Sen A.O.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 5 November, on motion by Senator Collard:
That the Senate take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report presented to the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment (Mr Cohen) by the Working Group on Rainforest Conservation was released to the public in September 1985. This paper has to be read in association with one prepared by the Standing Committee on Forestry of the Australian Forestry Council on a draft national forest strategy for Australia. Both those papers draw our attention to a number of very serious matters in the conservation of rainforests in Australia. Indeed, I am glad to observe that the report, in terms of rainforest conservation, is one which has the endorsement of all governments, including the Queensland Government and various other State governments throughout Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to make a point which is of some importance as far as my State of New South Wales is concerned. Just recently the Opposition parties in New South Wales released their own rainforest conservation strategy. The Shadow Minister responsible in this area, my colleague Tim Moore, the Member for Gordon, has produced and released a rainforest conservation strategy based upon these principles: First, a commitment has been given, not only on behalf of the Liberal Party in New South Wales but also on behalf of the National Party in New South Wales, that under a future coalition government in New South Wales there will be no logging in any of the New South Wales rain forests; secondly, there will be no changes made to any of the existing national and State park boundaries in New South Wales; thirdly, there will be compensation for disadvantaged landholders; and finally, my colleague Mr Moore will be the Minister responsible for the administration of the State's parks and of this forest policy in a government headed by Nick Greiner, who has publicly endorsed this policy.

It is of some importance to indicate that there are a number of recommendations of very great significance in this report. The first occurs at page 100 of the report, where the working group recommends to the Commonwealth Government the `consideration of nomination of rainforest areas in Australia for World Heritage listing'. I believe this to be a matter of very considerable significance. The rainforests of this country are greatly endangered. The rainforests of the world are endangered. A recent article in the Sydney Morning Herald indicated that 11 million hectares of tropical rainforest-an area the size of Austria-is being destroyed each year. At this rate 225 million hectares of rainforest will be lost by the year 2000 and with it will disappear an estimated 10 to 20 per cent of the earth's animal species. This is a situation which cannot be tolerated. The genetic diversity of the rain- forests and the existence of the so-called Vavilo centres within the rainforests, which are the pools of genetic differentiation for animal and plant species, are matters of very great significance.

There are a couple of other points in this report to which I think attention must be drawn. One comment in regard to the rainforests in Tasmania is of significance. Page 39 of the report indicates that the long term maintenance of Tasmanian rainforests depends on the exclusion of fire. One therefore reads with very great concern the reports from Tasmania of the recent fire at the end of October. Admittedly, it did not take place within a rainforest area, but it occurred as the result of a burn-off that was supposed to be managed by the Tasmanian National Parks and Wildlife Service but which got out of hand and did an enormous amount of damage, threatening forests, and endanger bird species.

The last point I make very briefly is that it is most important that the Commonwealth re-examine the backdown in which it has been involved as far as the Daintree is concerned. Problems have been indentified there-for instance, the threat to the significant species of the gastric-brooding frog and a number of other wildlife species which need to be conserved and which are of enormous significance and of potential benefit from a medical and scientific point of view. I believe the problems that have been identified expose one of the great weaknesses of this Government in terms of the rather craven way it has handled the Daintree and the rather craven way in which it has not been prepared to take on an issue of national significance and to respond effectively to the legitimate demands that have been made for the preservation of that rainforest area.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This report on rainforest conservation is unexceptionable, even commendable, except that it has not saved a single tree. Indeed, in the course of its printing and publication I have no doubt that it has consumed paper that has destroyed a number of trees. The fact that this report is in the realm of words rather than action is its main fault. I could scarcely disagree with its recommendations since they are very much in line with my own private member's Rainforest Preservation Agreements Bill 1982-four years ago-which is listed for debate later today but which we all know will not pass because both the Government and the Opposition have expressed opposition to it. This in itself is an eloquent testimony to the double-talk with which this issue is approached continually by the Liberal and National parties and the Labor Party, which want to duck out for dimly perceived electoral purposes, especially in Queensland. Let us face the truth over that.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Democrats for many years have been very concerned about the organised destruction of our rainforests and the extremely leisurely attitude of the Government to what in other nations would be properly regarded as national monuments. I refer to the 1000-year old giant trees in places like the Mount Windsor tableland in Queensland, the destruction of some of which I witnessed when I visited the Mount Windsor tableland a couple of years ago. Those big trees, which in other countries would be revered, almost worshipped, because of their age and value and the impossibility of replacing them, were destroyed so that they could become veneer on someone's furniture or boat. They have not added a single square metre of living space to an Australian home or business. They are there in the veneer business. It is about time we all got the word around that it is vulgar and in bad taste to stick rainforest veneers on the front of our furniture. What is wrong with good honest timbers which are solid all the way through? If Australians begin to realise that that timber is much more beautiful in the forest than on the front of their furniture, we might get a decent sort of attitude. Every time a big tree was brought down in that area-I had a look at this myself; I looked at the areas where the big trees had been brought down-a huge expanse of natural vegetation around was also damaged and virtually destroyed. It does not restore itself to its natural state. In the Mount Windsor tableland the areas around it became infested with a particularly nasty weed, the thorny Gympie weed or Gympie bush.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not thorny; it is stingy.

—It is stingy; that is right. Most Australians do not now agree with the tradition that began all this problem-if it moves, shoot it and if it does not, chop it down. There is a general understanding in the community that we have one of the lowest rates of afforestation in the world. People now generally understand that we live in symbiosis with other living things-plants and animals-and that indeed that relationship keeps us alive. If growing things did not provide oxygen and use carbon dioxide we would all very quickly gasp ourselves to death in our own production of that waste. Forests also affect climate importantly. Elsewhere in the world this is understood. It is not understood in Australia and is particularly not understood in this place, judging from the response to a very reasonable Bill which is my own but which was not of my authorship. It was designed and drafted by Mr Justice Murray Wilcox who was then President of the Australian Conservation Foundation. It was the Australian Conservation Foundation's Bill and it was very reasonable and very good. The recommendations are confirming what that Bill said four years ago. It is an indictment of this Parliament that two governments over that time have done nothing about it.

SPEECH.PARA: I would just like to make a brief, important contrast of Australia's situation with that of China, a much poorer country than Australia with much smaller resources. According to the People's Daily on 29 June this year, an enormous effort is being made to increase the forests of China. I saw some of this when our delegation was there a while ago. There has already been a 50 per cent increase in forest cover since 1949. In that year trees covered only 8.6 per cent of China; the figure is now 12.7 per cent. By the end of the century the Government of China intends to make it 20 per cent. By contrast, the most ambitious figure we can get for Australia is 5.5 per cent of forest cover. I suggest it is about time we got our act together, stopped the bad joke of subsidising the Japanese to take away our woodchips and gave this matter the serious consideration it deserves.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report entitled `Rainforest Conservation in Australia' is, without doubt, a very useful document. Many areas appear to be covered on a rather incomplete basis at this stage and many areas stand out as requiring considerably more work. There seems to be little understanding of what various State authorities have done over the last decade or so and what they have in train to recognise the adequate differences between the various types of rainforest in Australia. The overall broad brush method is not really the way to solve these sorts of problems. The report shows very clearly that there is a need for much more data, especially an accurate inventory, and for considerably more objective research. The document will be very useful for debates and discussions, particularly in the wide area of preservation and conservation; and the need to appreciate that is in the report. Mr Thompson, in his letter to the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment (Mr Cohen), raised that matter when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: Different interpretations were placed on the word `protect' in the recommended Commonwealth Rainforest Conservation Policy. The views of the timber industry and Queensland forestry authority representatives would have been better represented by the word `conserve', whilst the views of the conservation representatives would have been better represented by the word `preserve'.

It is not possible to remove sociological and economic considerations from any investigation. Those who would try to ignore the importance of the reality of life-that man and the environment must co-exist-are preventing a reasonable and meaningful discussion on this subject. The report shows that no drop-outs, dropins, disruptionists, crackpots, sensationalists, headline hunters, or whatever they might be, should be allowed to get in the way of a reasonable discussion on this subject. I consider the recommendations listed in paragraph 7.2 of the report to be quite predictable and to cover very adequately a range of interests represented by the Working Group on Rainforest Conservation. The balance to be achieved will be interesting and not without complications, but with this document as a starting point I am sure that practical and reasonable solutions can be achieved.

The Senate Standing Committee on Industry and Trade in its 1981 report on forests dealt with rainforest management and spent much time deliberating on rainforests, their management and conservation. Most Australians have a broad view of and very real interest in conservation, as they do in the nation as a whole. It must be looked at as to where it fits into the Australian nation. I commend the report as a very useful document from which research can be planned and from where a true inventory can be prepared. Those charged with the management of the country and of the forests can really settle in and start to do some meaningful work.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join with my colleagues who have pointed out the significant matter that the report entitled `Rainforest Conservation in Australia' discloses. The fact that this is a unanimous report is important, because it covers people coming from all parts of the country who are concerned with and are highlighting the problem which is before us. It is important, therefore, that it should not be allowed to pass this Parliament without great consideration. I believe there is a need for very urgent and extreme consideration of the problem. I agree with my colleague Senator Puplick that the world heritage application should be proceeded with with extreme urgency. For various reasons, it is a good idea and will bring the matter under proper control. The problem is that very little rainforest is left and very little is accessible to people. By `accessible to people' I mean not only to loggers, but also to Australians and visitors. I think the world heritage application will be important from the tourist point of view, quite apart from other matters. This is a serious problem. I would have thought that the Government would have shown more urgency in dealing with the matter. Mr Cohen expressed the Commonwealth Government's concern for rainforest conservation when opening the Rainforest Conference in Cairns in February 1984. As reported on page 77 of the report, he stated:

SPEECH.PARA: There is no doubt in my mind that the national Government has a role in protecting a resource that is part of our national heritage. At present rainforests are one of the most threatened parts of that heritage.

I do not think the actions of the Government have been other than dilatory. Recently we had an offer which shows that the Queensland Premier at least is prepared to look at. It is a fact that approximately 80 per cent of the total rainforest area has gone and very little remains now that could be logged. On page 79 of the report it is stated:

The most significant of the areas liable to future logging are in northern Queensland, where 1986 will mark the end of an era of more than 100 years of virgin rainforest logging, as virgin areas available for logging will have been worked through. There are also substantial areas of virgin rainforest in Tasmania where logging has been deferred until 1988 pending a comprehensive inventory and assessment by State Government departments.

It is very important that this matter is worked on very swiftly. Likewise, I think that the application for world heritage listing should be attended to without delay. I believe that the report, which I have not had the opportunity of studying completely, ought to be looked at. I know that the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation is looking at the problem the road has caused to the Great Barrier Reef next to the Daintree Rainforest because the flooding of silt and other elements onto the reef has probably done permanent damage. I hope the Committee will report on that matter very soon. I hope that this Government will show much greater enthusiasm, the sort of enthusiasm it showed in regard to the world heritage in Tasmania a few years ago. That enthusiasm seems to have evaporated. The Government seems to think that it has done all that needs to be done and, therefore, does not need to bother; it is more conscious that it might upset somebody. I hope the Government will realise that a lot of people in this country feel very strongly about these issues and expect the Government now to protect and preserve what remains of our rainforest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not intend to enter this debate but I must say that I think the Liberal Party is trying to have its cake and eat it too. One section of the Liberal Party is saying that the Government has not been diligent enough in the protection of rain forests while another section says that we go too far. What the Liberal Party is trying to do is to get the conservationists' vote on the one side and the red-neck vote on the other. I see Senator Collard looking at me. It is interesting to note that the National Party of Australia remains ominously silent today.
—Senator Collard has already spoken, that is why.

—He can, of course, speak again. In Senator Puplick's absence, we amended the Standing Orders. Honourable senators can speak more than once on papers. He can take the opportunity to do so again during the consideration of General Business. I would have thought that on such an important issue Senator Collard may have stood up to correct both Senator Puplick and Senator Missen; or does he agree with both those honourable senators? Is the Opposition just having two bob each way, like it always does? I agree with something Senator Missen said when he pointed out what a tourist attraction rain forests are. I was not a supporter of the building of the Daintree road. I have been up there and I believe that, if anything, a proper road should have been put down because one cannot hire a four wheel drive vehicle within 100 miles of the Daintree. Every conservationist and forest lover around-there are many of them-has hired them. They are all using that road, incidentally, although I would not accuse them of being hypocritical because it is one of the few ways to see the forest. The Daintree Rainforest is a major tourist attraction.

SPEECH.PARA: People such as Senator Archer come into this chamber and start saying that one has to think about the social, economic and all the other consequences. The rain forest is an asset that will bring hundreds of thousands of people to Australia over the next decade and centuries to see these sorts of unique areas. It is no good wiping them off. Senator Missen asks us: `Why are you not more enthusiastic?' Every time this Government or any Federal Labor government takes on a State government, all the Liberals opposite, bar one I admit, say: `No, States' rights are more important than rainforests or anything else'. They all jump out from under their rocks and start pushing the States rights' barrel so we can do nothing. So we are a little more cautious in our approach these days. We do not jump in like we used to because we find--

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—We do not jump in like we used to because we find that one can never trust what Senator Crichton-Browne's Party says. One moment it is supporting a constitutional amendment because it is in power. The next moment, the moment it is in opposition, it is opposing it. It has no consistency at all. That is because it is a pack of individuals without principle who just go on personality.

SPEECH.PARA: I rose to make the point that the Liberal Party speaks with a forked tongue, that it is split on this issue and is trying to get the best of all worlds. Senator Archer and others are taking the gung ho, private enterprise, chop it down at all costs approach. Senator Puplick, Senator Missen and others are taking the approach that the Government has not done enough. I invite Senator Collard to tell us what the National Party's attitude is. It is the National Party State Government that is chopping down every tree it can find in Queensland. I would have thought that such a pragmatic person as Senator Collard would realise that in the end there is more money in tourism than there is in wood chipping.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I hope that you are as generous with the Standing Orders as Senator Robert Ray is.
—Order! Senator Collard, is it your intention to speak on the same paper?
—It sure is, Mr Acting Deputy President.
— Under Standing Orders you are debarred from speaking twice on the same paper.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, you are not as generous as Senator Ray.
—Seek leave to make a statement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collard Sen S.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLARD
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I seek leave to make a statement, seeing I have been challenged.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not abuse the privilege the Senate has given me. Senator Ray has challenged me. Unfortunately, he was not in the chamber the other day when I offered a few words on the report entitled `Rainforest Conservation in Australia'. As has been pointed out by Senator Missen, the Queensland Government played a part in the report and, indeed, is quite happy with it. Undoubtedly, there would be areas of definition where we would probably differ with some of the conservationists but I say here and now that there would be a lot of common ground between me and the genuine conservationists. I have already found that to be true in some of my discussions with those who are genuinely concerned about conservation. I pointed out the other day-I suggest that Senator Ray read the Hansard-that a large area of the existing rain forest will not be logged for various reasons. It is in national parks and the Department of Forestry has set it aside. This is where I differ already with some of the conservationists. We believe that some of the areas that are being logged can be selectively logged and then locked up for 30, 40 or 50 years.
—But you agree with the point about tourism giving more money?

—I do. I use this opportunity to mention the Daintree road which Senator Robert Ray so rightly mentioned. The Daintree Rainforest is not being logged except by one very small operator who has the ability to log about 700 hectares out of a total of 190,000 hectares. His allowed take is somewhere around 3,120 cubic metres per annum which he has not yet taken. A lot of the Daintree Rainforest is locked up in national parks. As far as Daintree road is concerned, when the Daintree area was made a national park it was in the full understanding by the National Parks and Wildlife Service that that bit would be excised for a road. Only one and a quarter kilometres of it-this is where I ended my speech the other day-actually runs through the `primeval, pristine rainforest'. Once one gets beyond that one is starting to get into eucalypts, hardwood ridges and open grasslands, the result of what happened when the Aborigines husbanded the earth by burning it every two or three years. The road only runs through that small area of rain forest. It is high stress rain forest area anyhow in that for aeons it has been subject to cyclones and knocked around pretty badly. The nearest of the areas which are considered by the Department of Forestry, the National Parks and Wildlife Service and the conservation movement as quite unique with unique flora would not come within 10 kilometres of the road.

SPEECH.PARA: I agree with Senator Ray. The road should be better. The rain forest is a great tourist attraction for those people who want to go to Queensland to look at it. The road along the coast will be magnificent as is the road all the way from Cairns. I have advocated that the national highway should be extended through that area up to Cooktown and brough up to bitumen standard so that one does not get much run off and the road is properly made. That would allow people to see what is a magnificent area and what is some of the last rain forest in Queensland. The Queensland Government has a good record in regard to its national parks and forestry. It intends to continue that record. As I said, a vast amount, 66 per cent, of the rain forest in Queensland will not be logged.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me inject my views into the debate on the report entitled `Rainforest Conservation in Australia'.
—Oh, shut up!
—Does the Minister have a complaint to make? Given the amount of time he takes up in this place, he ought to be generous enough to concede a few minutes to me.
—It was a silent prayer.

—The Minister should not start praying when I get to my feet. I wish to express a view that we ought not be considering roads, tourists or four wheel drive vehicles for areas such as the Daintree rainforest. It is an area which should be allowed to exist with as little impact by man as possible. I would have thought that that would have been the approach to many of these areas. They are quite unusual areas and should be permitted to exist as wilderness areas. For that reason one ought to question the building of roads so that people can race through these areas at 80 kilometres an hour and catch an occasional glimpse of greenery and, shall we say, quietness along with the other impressions one gets. That really is not good enough. That is the way we have tended to go for so long-getting fleeting glimpses of great beauty. I have a view that this area, and many other areas in Queensland and the rest of Australia, should not be misused in this way. I wish to put the counter view that tourism is not an absolute essential and in this case we should protect the forest. If we are going to have tourism, we will need facilities and we will need roads. If we have roads they will be travelled on by four-wheeled drive vehicles.
—Senator Georges, would you agree that we should get Senator Robert Ray to put a pack on his back and walk through the area and that it would be good for him?
—How about giving someone else a bit of a go, Senator Mason? You are rattling on like a pebble in a can.

—I say to the honourable senators who are interjecting that they may carry on. If they wish to take up the next two minutes, they may do so. There are certain areas where people can enjoy the environment in the ways that have been suggested by several honourable senators. But there are some areas that ought to be protected from human intrusion and the Daintree is one of them. So we have to broaden our concept.
—It seems to me that the Labor Party is talking with a forked tongue.

—I am not like some people in this place who do not speak with a forked tongue but who seem to talk out of both sides of their mouths at once. I have noticed several such people on the opposite side of the chamber. I might even suggest that Senator Collard does that. If I remember rightly, Senator Collard was very close to nature at one stage of the game. His family was responsible for the introduction in the Maleny area of what is now known as Collard's curse.
—What about Archer's curse?

—No, it was called Collard's curse. I am speaking about kikuyu grass which the honourable senator's family introduced into Maleny and which spread to the exclusion of practically every other type of growth in that area. When Senator Collard starts to talk about conservation he ought to consider that he places the needs of pastoralists and exploiters before the needs of the environment. Caring for the needs of the environment, in many cases, means that we have to exclude humans. I get back to the point that there ought to be a reduction in human impact on certain areas within Australia, and one area is the forests in the northern part of Queensland.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report and Text of Ministerial Statement

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 5 November, on motion by Senator Collard:
That the Senate take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collard Sen S.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLARD
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —On Tuesday I moved the motion that the Senate take note of the paper. I shall take up almost where Senator Georges left off in the debate on the report entitled `Rainforest Conservation in Australia'. I say to the honourable senator that kikuyu grass has stood us in good stead in many a drought. But he is right. We have to make up our minds whether we will provide food and fibre for this nation or whether we will not. I happen to be one who believes that there is a balance and that a lot should be preserved, but in those days much of the rainforest in Maleny was cleared. My farm is called Cedar Park. The bullockies called it that because of the good stand of cedar that was on it.
—There is none left.

—It used to be there. The farmhouse was made out of one beech log. The stump of the tree is still there. It was all pitsawn in those days. It was hard work for the people who were opening up that country.
—It would be better if it were still growing.

—If it were still growing, we would probably be importing many more items and our current account deficit would be a lot worse off. As I have said, there has to be a balance. I am speaking on a report which, in case anybody who may be listening is unaware, is entitled `National Conservation Strategy for Australia'. It follows pretty closely the report on rain forest conservation in Australia that we have just talked about. If I do nothing else, I wish to read into the record the definition of conservation which is in both documents. They both have the same definition. This definition would probably help people to understand conservation, because currently it means all things to all people. The report states:

SPEECH.PARA: Conservation is the management of human use of the biosphere so that it may yield the greatest sustainable benefit to present generations while maintaining its potential to meet the needs and aspirations of future generations. Thus conservation is positive, embracing preservation, maintenance, sustainable utilisation, restoration, and enhancement of the natural environment. Living resource conservation is specifically concerned with plants, animals and micro-organisms, and with those non-living elements of the environment on which they depend. Living resources have two important properties the combination of which distinguishes them from non-living resources: they are renewable if conserved; and they are destructible if not.

That definition is written into both documents, and I could not disagree with it. It is significant that members of the committees involved in preparing both these reports were from all structures of society in Australia-from government departments and from the conservation movement-and they were all able to agree on that definition. Of course, there will always be argument on the interpretation of that definition, but it is not a bad definition. Senator Georges spoke with some passion, as he usually does, about excluding humans from a forest. I put to him that since man came out of the cave, man has always had an effect, for better or worse--

TALK.START.PARA: —Half of the Liberal Party has not come out of the cave yet.

—Senator Robert Ray may not have. But man, for better or worse, or just for his own use, has had an effect on the environment. Whether we like it or not, he has done so either directly or indirectly through the introduction of diseases, animals or whatever. I do not think that even the most ardent conservationist could see himself going back to the cave. So man has had and will contiue to have an effect on his environment. We have to get to broad agreement on how we can best look after the environment as we find it. Attitudes have changed already amongst farmers, loggers, governments and conservationists. There is a lot of common ground and a lot more than most people would realise. So I commend both documents to those who are concerned about this great nation of ours. The report that we are now debating does contain broad philosophies on which just about everyone would agree. Once again, there will always be differences of interpretation, but both of them are good, working documents and provide a good base upon which we may start.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The final report of the Interim Consultative Committee entitled `National Conservation Strategy for Australia' is the culmination of one part of the development of conservation strategy in Australia which proceeded from an initiative of the Fraser Government. The interest which the former Prime Minister had in areas of conservation was well known. As one of the initiatives of his Government, in December 1981 the first seminar on this question was held. That lead to the publication of a report entitled `Towards a National Conservation Strategy', which was the basis for discussion at a number of meetings which were subsequently held and which culminated in a conference held in Canberra in June 1983. The chairman of that conference was Sir Rupert Myers. The conservation strategy conference laid down three principal objectives. They remain within the report which we are debating at the moment and they are as follows: Firstly, to maintain essential ecological processes and life support systems; secondly, to preserve genetic diversity; and, thirdly, to ensure the sustainable utilisation of species and ecosystems. The World Conservation Strategy 1980 expands on that third point and states its objective as being:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . to ensure the sustainable utilisation of species and ecosystems (notably fish and other wildlife, forests and grazing lands), which support millions of rural communities as well as major industries.

That goes very much towards the definition which Senator Collard mentioned in his speech a few moments ago. That conservation strategy, adopted on a world level, has been endorsed and modified to provide the national conservation strategy for Australia, and the final report of the Interim Consultative Committee is before the Senate at the moment. I think that it is important to indicate the section of the report on pages 7 and 8 which deals with the role of government. The report states:

Australia has a complex, mixed economy where the private and public sectors are inextricably linked at all strata, nowhere more so than in regard to decisions and actions affecting the use of land, water and living resources. Governments in Australia have primary and recognised functions to protect the integrity of these national resources.
It continues:

To provide for sustainable economic development and growth in the nation's economy, the deterioration of Australia's living resource base must be reversed. For this to occur, governments at all levels must adopt a more cohesive and long term perspective and must work together with the community with more resolve, resources and consistency than in the past.

The important thing arising from this statement, which I hope all honourable senators will endorse, is the clear indication that sustainable economic development and growth in the nation's economy require that that deterioration which has already taken place in Australia's living resource base must now be reversed. I think that the discussion which has proceeded on this report and the rainforest report which preceded it indicated the awareness in the minds of a number of honourable senators of the economic utility of conservation, its tourist potential and, indeed, the economic potential of conservation and conservation strategies. This report makes it clear that, in order to benefit in any sense, the current situation of the deterioration of our living resource base must be reversed. Therefore, those who take a view about the economic advantages to flow from pursuing conservation strategies must recognise that this document makes it clear that that does not mean continued exploitation at its current level. In fact, it means a reversal of the degree of exploitation of some of these resources which must be undertaken as a matter of urgency.

I conclude by saying that I am very proud of the fact that the Liberal Party of Australia, at its last Federal Council meeting, became the first political party in Australia to formally adopt, by resolution, the national conservation strategy as the basis for its own conservation policies. I pay tribute to the former shadow Minister, David Connolly, for having introduced the resolution to the Federal Council and having the national conservation strategy formally adopted as constituting the basis of the Liberal Party's conservation and environment policy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —The paper entitled `National Conservation Strategy for Australia' is a good start. However, it is just a start. Unfortunately, Australian leaders still have a cowboy mentality concerning the environment. As many honourable senators in this chamber have expressed, Australian leaders follow the concept of rip it off; move on; she'll be right, mate; the future will take care of itself. Environmental concern is considered a luxury that one can have when one has a full belly, one's wallet is full, one's farm is doing well, everything is going well and one has a new Mercedes in the garage. At that stage one can go in for environmental concern. That is absolute rubbish. Environmental concern should start first, not last. The report mentions the need for environmentally sensible and sustainable development rather than the short term rip-off concepts which are now so prevalent in Australia. However, the report fails to bite the bullet. At page 47 it states:

SPEECH.PARA: THE STRATEGY-A PRACTICAL APPLICATION
Recommendations in Brief

The Commonwealth should initiate discussions as soon as possible with relevant organisations with a view to commencing in 1986/87 a series of local, highly visible tree conservation and establishment projects to combat salinity and land degradation in selected catchments along the Murray and Darling Rivers and their tributaries.

Fine! Planting trees is wonderful. It is very safe and it is not controversial at all. Everybody loves to plant trees. I am sure that many honourable senators have planted trees, perhaps in front of the media or in front of a school group. Why plant trees when we cut down so many every day? We lose many trees every day. We ship them to Japan in the form of wood chips. Why do we avoid this major issue? The report explains why. At page 48 it states:
Despite its obvious good sense, the integration of development and conservation as advocated in the NCSA is still a novel concept to the bulk of the community.

The report claims that environmental concern is a novel concept. It may be a novel concept in this chamber, but it is not a novel concept to the community. Two weeks ago Spectrum Research Pty Ltd did a poll on wood chips. It polled people in Melbourne, Sydney and Brisbane. It found that 82 per cent of the people polled were against wood chipping.

TALK.START.PARA: —They were ignorant.

—A colleague from Tasmania, Senator Aulich, says that they were ignorant. He would imply that anybody who is against wood chipping is ignorant. I suppose that in his Tasmanian eyes, as he does support wood chipping, he would feel that anybody who was against wood chipping is ignorant. But these people have their eyes open. They know the dangers involved in wood chipping. They know what it is doing to our economy and our forests. Eighty-two per cent of the people polled in those major cities said there should be no wood chipping. Ten per cent joined our troglodyte friend from Tasmania and said that wood chipping is a good thing. Eight per cent said that they did not know. Why then do we not halt the wood chipping operations? Why does not the national conservation strategy take on wood chipping? It does not do so because it is afraid. It is afraid of the Senator Collards, the Senator Walterses and the Senator Aulichs of this world, those people who will preserve their right to rip off the environment at the expense of future generations.

SPEECH.PARA: What is the magnitude of the wood chipping? We are losing some four million metric tonnes of wood chips to Japan every year at a cost to Tasmania of $20m a year in direct subsidies. The cost to New South Wales is $10m a year. It is hard to tell what these figures mean but, for the benefit of the average person, let us look at the size of the Victorian Football League park, which is in the southern part of this country. The park comprises 3.2 hectares. Each week 125 hectares-that is, the equivalent of 40 VFL parks-are wood chipped. That is what this national conservation strategy for Australia is not facing. Until reports and honourable senators face the wood chip problem we simply will not have anything approaching a national conservation strategy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aulich Sen T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The issue that Senator Sanders raised is a very interesting one for all of us. I was fascinated to hear his comments about the future of Tasmania. They come from a man who sat in the State Parliament one night and voted to bring down a Labor government which, in a courageous decision that turned around politics in Tasmania, saved the Franklin River. That Labor government found no support at all from the honourable senator on the other side of the chamber. In fact, he helped to put Robin Gray into power in Tasmania. Today he complains about the fact that wood chipping will continue in Tasmania. It will continue because the conservation movement at large in Tasmania, despite his particular protestations to the contrary, does believe that the wood chipping industry is necessary for Tasmania and is possible within an appropriate environmental arrangement. In other words, Senator Sanders is out of touch with his own constituency in Tasmania.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators will have noticed that when he talks across the chamber to Senator Tate, myself or others he often says `You Tasmanians', as if he has drifted in from the United States of America and still believes that somehow or other his loyalty is to that country and not to Australia or Tasmania. It may be Senator Sanders's viewpoint that he is an alien who is here under sufferance to tell the truth to Australians and Tasmanians. Despite the fact that he is bleating like a sheep on the other side-I refuse to listen to him because he has had his chance here and there to say a few things-there are people in the conservation movement in Tasmania who used to support Senator Sanders and who believe the wood chipping industry must go on, that it is essential to Tasmania and that the 4,000 jobs that are created, indirectly and directly, by that industry simply cannot be written off with one stroke of Senator Sanders's pen. Those people are quite prepared to stand up and be counted. They will do so when the final decision is made about wood chipping in Tasmania. I believe at this stage, from what I have heard, that Senator Sanders will be left on his little lonesome. The interesting thing that will come out of it is that Senator Sanders will be able to retreat to the mainland to go from seminar to seminar and from meeting to meeting.
Honourable senators-Oh no!

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, he will be visited upon the rest of Australia, and honourable senators cannot avoid it. He will become a national figure, thank God, because he will be out of Tasmania most of the time. That means that politics in Tasmania will benefit from his absence and he will find his true constituency-those ignorant people on the mainland who have no idea about wood chipping, who have no idea how it really operates in a proper environmental arrangement. Those people can say what they like to Spectrum Research Pty Ltd polls-which in many cases has been wrong-and Senator Sanders can stay there with them; but, in Tasmania, a very large proportion of the population supports wood chipping if it is done in the proper way. That encompasses people from one end of the spectrum, people in the conservation movement, to those who would regard themselves as strong pro-developers. Senator Sanders is out of touch, and I suggest that when people look at him and hear what he has to say in this chamber they will believe that there are other people in this chamber who represent Tasmania a little more accurately than he does on this issue.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 5 November, on motion by Senator Kilgariff:
That the Senate take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have read the statement on immigration serving immigrants and Australia by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hurford). The document is interesting and obviously the Minister is very keen on his portfolio. In looking at the paper he has produced, one commends him for it. As secretary of the Opposition committee on immigration and ethnic affairs, I have noticed that on numerous occasions the Minister has assisted the Opposition backbench committee and there is a good liaison between him and the committee. It is also to be commended that at times the Minister and the shadow Minister have put joint press statements on immigration. This indicates that both the Government and the Opposition have a real interest in immigration and migrants.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to speak briefly to the paper, which is a fairly general one. It points out that the Minister envisages and hopes that migration will be raised from some 80,000 a year now to a figure in perhaps a year or within a few years of 100,000. I support that statement for I believe that even though we have difficulties with the problem of employment-and I suppose these days most nations have difficulties-migrants have brought enormous value to Australia. They have developed the industries of Australia and have contributed in so many ways that have made Australia what it is today. This has been demonstrated by the fact that until now some four million migrants have come to Australia. They have come from a hundred countries or more. When one looks around Australia now, whether in the main streets of towns or in schools, one notices the various hues and colours of skin and the various nationalities that now make up this country. I believe that Australia has been greatly enriched by the migrants from these many countries.

It is obvious that the Minister is concerned about illegal immigration. I do not say that he overstresses the problem, but obviously he wants to bring about a situation where he gets everybody to support him in taking strong measures. It almost sounds in the paper as if there is a plea for support for the taking of strong action against those who have come to Australia in various ways, but in any event they are illegal migrants. Illegal migrants must be found as much as possible. He or she must leave the country and, wherever possible, must be prevented from coming into Australia. I imagine every senator in this chamber would have some experience of people from overseas who, whether for family reunion or some other reasons, for a long time have been waiting to come to Australia. Illegal migrants are preventing, to some degree, those people from coming here. Therefore, I believe that the Minister has full support from all sections of the Senate in ensuring that illegal migrants are kept to a minimum. Senators move around the world and visit many countries. Last year I was fortunate to go to Indo-China in a delegation. I found there many migrants who wished to come to Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak briefly on the paper since the matter of illegal migrants has been raised. Although I do not suggest that we should in any way encourage people to come into this country illegally, or having come here on a visa or for some other reason we should not extend their stay and allow them to become illegal migrants, I think the matter should be viewed with extreme discretion and with some sympathy. I can understand why people desire to come here from places where there is less economic comfort, why they try to get past the barriers that we have erected against immigration, and why they endeavour to take short cuts. I agree with Senator Kilgariff that the short cut for one person makes it a long process for somebody else, and we cannot tolerate that. When this does occur and when there are compassionate grounds that become associated with those cases, I believe that they should be dealt with with sympathy.

SPEECH.PARA: I find it highly unacceptable that people who have committed this offence should be treated as criminals and be held as criminals. I believe that if there is to be some holding of people to prevent their absconding, they should be held not in criminal sections of gaols but in some other place. They should know that some progress is being made to have remand centres properly established for the holding of people and their families in reasonable comfort until such time as they are allowed to go back under their own efforts or are deported. Recently we looked at the conditions in the Brisbane gaol where people were held under warrants for being illegal immigrants. We discovered that because of the lack of facilities there they were held alongside people who were in that place because they had committed serious criminal offences. Sometimes illegal immigrants could remain in the gaol for five to six weeks. I suggest that should not be permitted. No person should be held in those conditions in custody because he or she has extended a period of stay or has endeavoured to come to this country with a desire to stay here. In Queensland the situation is so poor and conditions so overcrowded that I suggest to the Department that no person should be held in prison. In the circumstances the risk should be taken that the person may abscond and it may be difficult to pick him or her up again. Nevertheless, I believe that rather than imprisoning such people, we should give them that benefit and we should take the risk.

As long as we keep up these very restrictive barriers, people will endeavour to get to Australia illegally. People will go to all sorts of extremes to enter Australia. I know of one person who, having been refused entry to Australia, went to Papua New Guinea, paddled across to the Thursday Island group, came across to the Queensland coastline and then travelled all the way down to Brisbane, only to be arrested and placed in gaol. I would have thought that we should have allowed a person with that sort of determination to stay. There are people with tremendous determination and desire to come here and to stay. The sooner we extend and relax the quotas, and take more people despite our unemployment position, the better. We would not then have to face the problem of dealing with these people in such a harsh way.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There is only one minute left to discuss Government papers. I think it would be pointless to start discussion on a new paper in that time, so I shall rule that the time for consideration of Government papers has expired. We will now proceed to the consideration of other General Business.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 30 May, on motion by Senator Chipp:
That the Bill be now read a second time.
(Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Chipp's Nuclear Weapons Prohibition Bill 1985 seeks to prohibit the development, testing, manufacture, importation, transportation or storage of nuclear weapons in Australia by Australia or any other foreign power or company. The Bill is in all substantial details the same as the Bill with the same title which Senator Chipp lodged last year; it has not been redrafted or, apparently, rethought in the light of significant new commitments which Australia has entered into since that time.

SPEECH.PARA: The essential starting point in our consideration of the Bill is our firm belief that it is not necessary in either the establishment of our nuclear weapons free policy or in demonstrating our bona fides in applying it, to express that commitment in legislative form. The general objective of ensuring that Australia is and remains a nuclear weapons free country is entirely consistent with Australian Government policy. Australia is committed to this position both under the terms of the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons, which is already in force in Australia, and more recently the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty, in the drafting and acceptance of which we played the central role. No one can doubt, in the light of these treaties, the good faith of our commitment to Australia remaining nuclear weapons free. Our credentials are impeccable, and we do not need to support Senator Chipp's Bill or any other piece of legislation in this field to prove it.
Under the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty of 1968, to which Australia became a party in 1973, we are obliged:
not to receive, manufacture or acquire nuclear weapons or other nuclear explosive devices, nor to seek or receive assistance in their manufacture, that is Article II;

not to provide to non-nuclear weapons states source or special fissionable material or equipment for production of special fissionable material unless subject to safeguards, that is the obligation under Article III.2;
to accept safeguards on all peaceful nuclear activities under Article III.1;
to conclude a safeguards agreement with the International Atomic Energy Agency by virtue of Article III.4;
to facilitate exchange of equipment, materials and information for the peaceful uses of nuclear energy, that is Article IV.2;
to co-operate in the development of peaceful uses of nuclear energy, especially in the developing countries by Article IV.2; and
to pursue negotiations on cessation of the nuclear arms race, nuclear disarmament and general and complete disarmament by virtue of Article VI.
Under the terms of the SPNFZ Treaty Australia is again specifically and unequivocally obliged:
not to manufacture or acquire any nuclear explosive device, nor to seek or receive any assistance in the manufacture or acquisition of such devices-that is Article 3;
not to test or assist any other state to test such devices by Article 6;
not to station nuclear devices within our territory by Article 5;

to ensure that all peaceful nuclear activities within our territory shall be subject to full-scope safeguards-that is coverage of all facilities and nuclear material by IAEA safeguards, including regular inspections by IAEA personnel and materials accountancy procedures, that is Article 8;
to ensure that the export of nuclear material will be subject to the international non-proliferation regime based on the NPT and IAEA safeguards, that is Article 4; and finally
to accept verification of these obligations, not only under IAEA auspices but also through on-site inspections subject to a consultative committee established under the treaty, that is Article 8.
The SPNFZ Treaty also records the strong opposition of the parties to the dumping of nuclear waste at sea under Article 7.

Compared with the two treaties to which we are party, Senator Chipp's Bill is an ill-drafted and inappropriate means of achieving the objective of ensuring that Australia remains a nuclear weapons free country. There are a number of areas, for a start, where it may well be said that the Chipp Bill does not go far enough. For example, the Bill makes no provision for the effective enforcement of the obligations involved through systems of monitoring, surveillance and verification-none at all. Again, if one wanted an absolutely comprehensive legislative barrier erected, one would rule out-in a way that this Bill does not-the stockpiling or deployment of nuclear weapons from locations established within the territorial sea, not just on the Australian land mass. One would also rule out-in a way that this Bill does not seek to-the acquisition, manufacture or stockpiling of weapons by the Australian Government outside Australian territory.

There are other areas where the Bill manifestly goes beyond what the Australian Government would be prepared to contemplate under its present nuclear policy. The Bill, for example, would not allow dry-docking of nuclear capable ships under any circumstances. Our policy, however, is one of considering each request on its merits, taking into account technical and safety factors and the strategic and operational factors obtaining at the time. Senator Chipp's Bill would cut directly across the Government's established policy that it will not in any way endanger the safety of any allied or friendly ship or crew in need of access to Australian facilities. Another entirely legitimate activity, consistent with our present non-nuclear policy, which the Chipp Bill, read literally, would appear to rule out, is the maintenance of the research capacity necessary for us to be able to monitor and assess nuclear developments elsewhere, particularly in our own region.

There are other provisions in the Bill which the Government would find difficult to accept as it is presently drafted. The elaborate provisions, for example, relating to the seeking and issuing of injunctions, would seem to be, as a matter of strict law, wholly unnecessary, since such procedures are available under the general law for any breach of a statutory prohibition. Spelt out as they are, these provisions could well operate in practice as positive encouragement to the mischievous misuse of the legal process, with actions being taken for the sole purpose of embarrassing the Government of the day, whatever it is, in the conduct of its international relations.

It can hardly be thought that in rejecting this Bill we are in any way resiling from our commitment-embodied in our adherence to the non-proliferation and South Pacific nuclear free zone treaties-not to acquire nuclear weapons by any means, or store them on Australian soil. We have committed ourselves to those and many other obligations by our unequivocal adherence to the NPT and the SPNFZ treaties. On the other hand we have also, of course, committed ourselves to allowing the access of allied nuclear- capable ships to Australian ports and the passage of such vessels through Australian waters. Our position on all these matters is unequivocally clear, and we do not need to spell it out in legislation for the nature of those commitments to be understood, or for their binding nature to be apparent.

None of this is to say, however, that it is inappropriate under any circumstances to legislate in relation to any of the subject matter under discussion. It has been and remains the Government's intention to legislate to the extent necessary to implement our obligations under the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty and the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty. To the extent that domestic legislation is required under the Non-Proliferation Treaty, it either has been established, for example in the Customs (Prohibited Exports) Regulations, or is in an advanced stage of drafting, as with the comprehensive Nuclear Non-Proliferation (Safeguards) Bill which I hope to introduce into the Parliament later this session.

In relation to the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty, the Government has already decided that the Environment Protection (Sea Dumping) Act 1981 should provide for measures prohibiting dumping at sea of radioactive waste, and we will introduce, as soon as possible, further amending legislation to bring this about. Other possible measures on monitoring, surveillance and verification are being examined, including provisions for access rights, privileges and immunities for the inspectors provided for under the verification provisions of the treaty.

We believe that this combination of binding executive commitments, together with legislative provisions where technically necessary, will provide a comprehensive regime covering every one of the concerns inherent in Senator Chipp's Bill, and much more as well. The nature and extent of our commitment to ensuring that nuclear weapons are not installed on Australian soil stands in sharp contrast to the position of the Opposition as stated by Mr Peacock on 7 August this year. He said that the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty should not be accepted if it contained any provision banning the installation and storage of nuclear weapons on Australian soil. It was an extraordinary statement and an extraordinary demonstration of the gulf that divides the Government from the Opposition on these matters.

There is not the same gulf dividing the Government and the Australian Democrats in our response to the subject matter of this particular Bill. We are committed to a nuclear weapons free Australia, but we do not regard this Bill, or any measure like it, as an appropriate vehicle for demonstrating and establishing that commitment. We cede to no one in the strength of our commitment to those principles and make no apologies for choosing to express and observe them in our own way, and not the way mapped out for us-no doubt in all good faith-by Senator Chipp.

It is important that we in the Parliament not be diverted by a debate such as this from the fundamental and pressing objectives which I am sure the Australian Democrats share with the Government. This Government has made its position on nuclear non-proliferation unambiguous through its strong and active support of the NPT and the SPNFZ treaty. Our opposition to the acquisition, manufacture, development, testing and storage of nuclear weapons in or by this country is quite unshakeable. For this Government, our credentials on that issue cannot be questioned; our priority now is to use the arguments and approach that have led us to making Australia a nuclear weapons free country to advance the cause of arms control and disarmament internationally.

Our objective in that area-the achievement of balanced and verifiable reductions in the nuclear arsenals leading to their ultimate elimination-will not be advanced by directing our energies and limited resources to enshrining in domestic law the principles of a nuclear weapon free Australia to which this Government has obviously already committed itself. Rather, the real challenge lies in working vigorously in all the international forums available to us and through our bilateral contacts with other countries to convince the international community that the reduction and elimination of nuclear weapons is a task demanding the highest priority and the strongest commitment. That task calls for carefully thought out policies and initiatives, persistent and effective diplomacy, and the courage of our convictions.

It is worth while recalling what some of those policies and intitiatives have been, and what some of that diplomacy has involved. The Government has, for a start, made voluntary contributions to the world disarmanent campaign, the United Nations Institute for Disarmament Research, and the United Nations program for the International Year of Peace, in addition to Australia's normal contribution to the United Nation budget. Furthermore, the Government has enhanced Australia's capacity to contribute to peace research and disarmament diplomacy. Australia's disarmament diplomacy has been enhanced by the appointment of Australia's first Ambassador for Disarmament and a special disarmament adviser, and the the establishment of a disarmament and arms control branch and a peace and disarmament branch in the Department of Foreign Affairs. The Government has also funded a peace research centre at the Australian National University.

So that Australia can contribute to a proposed international seismic network to monitor ongoing nuclear testing and to establish the feasibility of verifying a nuclear test ban by seismic means, funding has also been provided to the Bureau of Mineral Resources to link a number of seismic stations on the Australian mainland and in the Antarctic to a national monitoring centre. This initiative is a direct practical contribution to the achievement of a viable comprehensive test ban treaty, which Australia has actively promoted at the United Nations General Assembly, the Conference on Disarmament, and at the Third Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty Review Conference. At that Third NPT Review Conference, held very recently, in September, Australia sought to defend the treaty as a cornerstone of international efforts to achieve a safer world through nuclear arms control, to maintain its effectiveness and to strengthen its effect. In achieving these aims Australia gave the highest priority to disarmament issues, an Australian initiative on full scope IAEA safeguards, and recognition of the recently negotiated South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty. Agreement on a call for a comprehensive test ban treaty was undoubtedly the single most important achievement of the Third Review Conference that has just taken place. It was particularly notable because it had not been possible to agree on such a call at the 1980 review conference. In all the work of the conference, and in particular the achievement of a final agreed communique, Australian diplomats-especially the Ambassador for Disarmament, Richard Butler-played an absolutely crucial role.

Again, under the Hawke Government, Australia has vigorously condemned French nuclear testing, suspended uranium exports to France, and participated with New Zealand and Papua New Guinea in a scientific mission which examined the environmental effects of testing at Mururoa Atoll. Australia has taken diplomatic and other measures to contribute to the development of a comprehensive chemical weapons convention, ratified the inhuman weapons convention, the Convention on the Prohibition of Military or any other Hostile Use of Environmental Modification Techniques, the 1954 Hague Convention for the Protection of Cultural Property in the Event of Armed Conflict, and signed the Convention on the Physical Protection of Nuclear Material. Australia has pressed for agreements to avoid an arms race in outer space and proposed measures to protect from attack all satellites and groundstations which contribute to the preservation of strategic stability and the monitoring of disarmament agreements. Australia has taken an active role in the ad hoc committee on the Indian Ocean, affirming Australia's readiness to join a consensus to hold an international conference on the question of an Indian Ocean zone of peace. Furthermore, at the United Nations, Australia has taken a much more active role in the promotion and support of arms control and disarmament resolutions. Last year at the Thirty-ninth United Nations General Assembly, Australia supported a resolution calling for a nuclear freeze.

This Government is, in short, in a whole variety of ways actively pursuing arms control, disarmament and nuclear non-proliferation in accordance with a coherent, properly thought out and realistic philosophy and policy framework. Australia is currently playing not only a very active but a very important role in international arms control negotiations and in encouraging progress in fundamentally important areas. The value of the contribution we are making is internationally recognised, and I commend our record to this chamber. This Government will continue to commit its energies to these challenges since we are firmly convinced that the measure of our success in those areas, rather than in distracting ourselves with sterile debate over unnecessary and inappropriate legislation, will be the real yardstick by which our effectiveness in contributing to the control of the nuclear arms race will be judged.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition, in line with the Government, will certainly vote against the Nuclear Weapons Prohibitions Bill 1985 and will do so very substantially for the reasons which the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) has already given. It was very revealing that Senator Evans spent a good deal of time in his contribution to this debate detailing the Government's so-called record in relation to matters of disarmament and, in particular, reduction in the nuclear arms race.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me say at the outset on behalf of the Opposition that we, of course, are equally anxious to ensure that there will be effective nuclear arms reductions and controls, with proper surveillance verification and so forth. We must all give the greatest encouragement, as we do, to the efforts that are at present taking place and the new efforts that are being made by the United States, and the Soviet Union to come to some effective agreement in this direction. Let me also emphasise-and I am sure the Government would be of the same view, or at least that section of the Government that Senator Evans represents-that these efforts should be made on a mutual basis and not on a unilateral basis. That is really the nub of the argument that will take place in this chamber on this Bill.

The Bill which we are considering was introduced by Senator Chipp and has been described, I think in some detail, by Senator Evans, and I do not need to go over that. It is founded fairly and squarely on a completely unilateralist approach to disarmament and to nuclear arms reduction and control. Senator Chipp made no bones about that in the reasons he gave for introducing this piece of legislation. But the division on this issue is between, on the one hand, the Australian Democrats and, on the other, the Government-as Senator Evans expressed it-and certainly the Opposition, in that we do not see a unilateralist approach as in any way appropriate or responsible in solving this major question of nuclear arms reduction and, for that matter, reduction of conventional weapons.

That is what this debate is primarily about, although there are as well some other very serious questions which I will deal with later. If Senator Chipp's Bill became law it would, of course, mean the destruction of the ANZUS Treaty. Senator Chipp, of course, makes no bones about the fact that he does not-

TALK.START.PARA: —Why would it do that? ANZUS does not even mention nuclear weapons.

—If Senator Chipp waited until he hears what I have to say, instead of interrupting me, we might get somewhere. In fact, the approach taken in this measure would give the United States the clearest warning in relation to visits to Australia by its warships-which may or may not carry nuclear weapons-that they cannot visit our ports.
—That is right.
—Of course it is right. Why is Senator Chipp interrupting me and shouting his head off as he did a minute ago?
—That is not even mentioned in ANZUS.

—Senator Chipp wants to have another debate as to what ANZUS means. I will be very happy to debate that with him some day. If I have time, I will do so this evening. The fact is-it is accepted and we can see it with our own eyes if we are prepared to consider what is happening in regard to New Zealand and the United States-that that breach of relationship which has occurred between New Zealand and the United States in relation to ANZUS concerns that question. Therefore, one cannot consider the effect of Senator Chipp's Bill without giving consideration to the result it would have on the ANZUS Treaty. That does not worry Senator Chipp because he and the Democrats do not believe in the ANZUS Treaty. They do not want the ANZUS Treaty.
—That is right.

—Yes, of course it is. We have now got it straight. Fortunately, with the assistance of Senator Chipp's rather dramatic interjections, the issues before the Senate are fairly clearly defined, before we hear any further from the Democrats in this debate. I want to speak in more general terms, as I had commenced to do, before turning to the details involved in that type of argument.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to make perfectly clear on behalf of the Opposition our complete agreement with, support of and deep concern for the success of the nuclear arms reduction program and discussions which are taking place between the United States and the Soviet Union. We believe that only by effective discussions of that kind will the world become a safer place and will we have, if not entirely removed, at least alleviated, the tremendous threat which has been of such deep concern to so many people throughout the world and, of course, in Australia. The Opposition fully supports that approach, that is, mutual reduction of arms; not the sort of approach which Senator Chipp and his Democrats believe in. Senator Vallentine will no doubt tell us where she stands on this matter; I will not anticipate what she will say in this debate. Where they differ from us on that issue is that they want to see us make some grand gesture of support for unilateral disarmament by Australia, regardless of what may occur between the super-powers.

Let me also state, in light of the lengthy pleading by Senator Evans on behalf of the Government as to the so-called actions that it has taken in regard to these questions, that it was the coalition Government which signed the Non-Proliferation Treaty on behalf of Australia. Let there be no appropriation by this Government of all virtue in regard to that Treaty. Certainly, it was ratified by the Whitlam Government and certainly this Government has properly participated in the recent five-yearly review of that Treaty. But it was the coalition parties when in government which signed that Treaty and we have the strongest and firmest adherence to it. We wish to see the widest possible adherence to it by the nations of the world. It will be only by world wide support for this treaty that the people of the world will have some greater assurance of security from the threat of nuclear destruction. So clearly, we in the Opposition fully support that treaty. We welcome and are pleased about the success that the recent five-year review of that treaty achieved. That is today: There could be another debate on another day. Indeed, all reports-we have not yet had the opportunity to consider them fully-indicate that it was a useful and successful meeting.

I come now to the very unpleasant and quite unjustified accusation made by Senator Evans in this debate today. It was a quite gratuitous accusation in the light of the sort of debate we are having on this important matter-namely, that the Opposition is completely opposed to the line the Government has been taking in relation to the development of the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone and, indeed the then Leader of the Opposition indicated that it was the policy of the Opposition, presumably, even to encourage the storage of nuclear weapons on Australian soil. In the statement of 7 August this year, to which Senator Evans referred, Mr Peacock pointed out that one effect of the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty which the Government has entered into was to raise the issue as to whether that treaty, if given full effect by Australia, would prevent home porting in Australia of allied warships and particularly United States warships. Mr Peacock said that such a situation may well be required if Australia were under the sort of threat to which the ANZUS Treaty would apply and if, in putting into effect the obligation of that treaty or of the American alliance on a broader sense, home porting of that nation's ships or any other nuclear powered warships in Australia were required for the defence of Australia. In fact, Mr Peacock said:
. . . the Prime Minister must give a categorical assurance that the agreed nuclear free zone will not rule out any possibility of future United States home porting within the zone or Australia.

That was because the provisions of the treaty will prevent the storage in Australia in any way of nuclear weapons. That brings me to the issue we debated at great length in this Parliament nearly two years ago about the dry-docking of the HMS Invincible in Sydney. We can recall the ambiguities, the confusions and the contortions that the then Minister for Defence as well as the Government, as represented in this chamber, were making about that very vital issue-namely, whether the Invincible could be dry-docked in Sydney because it had a major problem. Of course, the British Government was not prepared to say whether it was carrying nuclear weapons. That is a sort of situation that could occur at any time, even without a situation of conflict or threatened conflict. It could occur with our nuclear allies, either Britain or the United States. This is a problem which undoubtedly arises under the terms of that Pacific treaty and of any legislation, if the Government is going literally to give effect to the treaty, as Senator Evans has been talking about. It is a problem which, as I have already indicated, arises under Senator Chipp's Bill.

That is certainly a concern which the Opposition has expressed. But to use that to indicate that somehow the Opposition is in favour of Australia becoming a storage point for nuclear weapons is quite unjustified and untenable and cannot be in any way concluded from the statement Mr Peacock made, to which I have referred. That is tantamount to alleging that the Opposition would, presumably, denounce the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty. I do not know whether that is the extent of the allegation Senator Evans was making. If it is, let me nail it as a complete and utter misrepresentation of the Opposition's position.

Mr Acting Deputy President, I am sorry that I had to divert from the terms of the Bill before us in order to deal with that unpleasant and, as I have said, unjustified accusation by Senator Evans on behalf of the Government. I must say that I was rather amused by Senator Evans's defence of the Government in opposing this Bill. He said that there did not need to be any legislation to give effect to the Government's high moral stance in relation to nuclear weapons. Senator Evans has expressed a somewhat welcome degree of maturity in this regard. Of course, until now he has always expressed the most tender faith in the solution of problems by legislation.
