—Honourable members opposite keep going back to this cultural cringe. They say `This Ambassador is not worth listening to; the Conciliation and Arbitration Act is not worth reading' and so on. Anyhow, the thrust of the matter is there.
—Get stuck into them.

—I do not have to get stuck into them because the statistics that show how the Australian economy is running get stuck into them. The Opposition has run around looking for figures that indicate that something is wrong with the Australian economy. Having searched and searched, it has come up with one thing, and it has been talking about it all day-a fall of some cents in the Australian dollar. It says: `There we are; we will create a great campaign in this Parliament'. It is not the sort of campaign that will fool the Australian people when they look at all the statistics that should be considered, when they see the falling unemployment rate, when they see that overseas opinion about the way this Government is going is very favourable. Apparently what the Australian people think is irrelevant to the Opposition's consideration of how things go, and it has resorted to two things. Firstly, this alleged disaster in the fall of the dollar and, secondly, the trade union movement, which the Opposition hopes to use as a scapegoat, as an object of hate, to enable it to crawl back to power in some way.

SPEECH.PARA: I think that the people of Australia who are listening to this will agree that it is a pretty poor effort that that is the way the Opposition goes about doing things. This Government, in contrast to how things were in 1981, 1982 and into 1983, is bringing back to Australia a sense of self-respect and an economy that is going forward. If anything is going forward too rapidly, it needs the restraint of interest rates. If that was not so the economy would overheat. A couple of years down the line, when the next election is held, the policies of this Government will be well and truly vindicated.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President--
—This will be good, if it's going to be another union bash.

—No, it will not be a union bash at all, Senator. First of all, I congratulate my friend Senator Cooney on his very enjoyable and entertaining remarks. He is a man of infinite legal experience and wisdom. I thought his remarks tonight made it patently obvious that, in gaining that legal wisdom, he had had a lot of experience in defending hopeless cases. He did it very well tonight! More seriously, I wish to pick up and comment on a couple of points which Senator Cooney made. It seemed to me that several of his remarks tonight epitomised the fundamental mistake that the Hawke Labor Government is making in terms of achieving the objectives that it says it strives to achieve.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no point in Senator Cooney talking about compassion, social equity and social cost, implying that one political party has a concern for these matters and the other political parties do not, without acknowledging and recognising any feelings of that nature that any politician, political party or member of the community has. They are fine words only, if they are not achieved in the context of hard, rational, thought-out economic policies. We might say to ourselves that economics is a hard and a dismal science, but it has been proved beyond all doubt throughout history that an ignoring of economic rationality is the surest way to avoid bringing compassion, care and social equity to our people. One just cannot ignore economics in the way it was tonight. One cannot care for a growing community unless one has a growing economy. There is no alternative to that.

Senator Cooney criticised the Opposition for having grabbed at an individual statistic over the last few days-he said that we plucked it out and cited it out of context-namely, a statistic reflecting the fall in the value of the Australian dollar. I put it to Senator Cooney that it was not an individual plucking out of a statistic. It was a highlighting of a statistic resulting from a combination of factors that affect our economy. If we had better achievements and better results in those other fundamental parts of our economy, we would not be seeing the falling dollar and, by definition, the day by day fall in Australian living standards that that falling dollar leads to.

Senator Cooney spoke of housing costs and I agree with his concern, but there is no way one will get housing costs down unless one gets inflation and interests rates down. In a situation now where the Government is presiding over the highest level of interest rates in this country for a least half a century-and on some people's calculations for a century, one will do the people of this country a grave disservice in trying to enable them to get adequate housing and shelter.

I want to use the occasion of this cognate second reading debate on the Appropriation Bills to do three things. I want to attempt to debunk the myth which has so skilfully and assiduously been developed by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer (Mr Keating), with a bit of help from their friends in the media, over the past two and a half years that this Hawke Labor Government has demonstrated itself to be an effcient economic manager, and a more efficient economic manager than the previous coalition Government. Secondly, I want to record my grave concern about where the Australian economy is at the moment and where it is heading. Thirdly, I would like to make a few suggestions as to what we should be doing about it.

It is inevitable that the Government will portray anyone who raises concerns about the present level of performance and the likely future direction of the economy as just another prophet of doom. I guess I would do so, too, if I were in the Government's position. That is politics. But in my remarks tonight I hope that I will present myself as a political economist rather than just a politican, because the issues facing Australia are such that they should be beyond purely party politics. If they are not and if we do not reach some better measure of agreement as to which way this economy is going in identifying the present situation, heaven help us in finding the solution to our problem. It is about time that the Government started taking note of what economists in this country are saying. If it does not do so, the road ahead for all Australians will be even rockier than it will be in any case.

Let me say a few words about the first issue I want to deal with, and that is the myth that has been so skilfully developed by the Government, with some help from its friends in the media, that it is an efficient economic manager. How do we judge whether a government is an efficient economic manager? It is not easy. One cannot just look at the results in terms of employment, inflation, interest rates, output growth and so on. These results are often influenced by events outside the Government's or the nation's own control. The Whitlam Government was obviously influenced, to its disadvantage, by the first oil price shock in 1973. The Fraser Government was equally obviously influenced to its disadvantage by the world recession and the Australian drought in 1981 and 1982. The present Hawke Labor Govenment's results have been influenced in the opposite direction-in a favourable direction by the growth of the American economy since late 1982 and by the breaking of the drought in early 1983. Measured economic results have to be treated very cautiously when used to assess the economic management efficiency of any government. But with those qualifications, there are certain criteria against which any government's economic management efficiency can be assessed.

These criteria include at least the following: Has the Government been a prudent manager of its spending and taxation powers, bearing in mind that the only money governments have for spending comes at least eventually from taxpayers? That is an important criterion on which a government can be judged. Another criterion is whether the Government has taken action to maintain the value of our currency, both within Australia and against other currencies. Has it provided the right environment for the encouragement of lasting new job creation through economic growth? On each of these counts the performance of the Hawke Labor Government falls well behind that of its predecessor, the Fraser coalition Government.

Let us look at a few facts for once and forget about the myths. What about good management in spending and taxation? In the seven years of the Fraser Government, government spending grew on average by 2.2 per cent each year. That is very careful and prudent management-in fact, it is the most careful and most prudent economic management displayed by any government in Australia's post-war history. In the first two years of the Hawke Government, the average annual increase in its spending was more than three times greater than the 2.2 per cent of the Fraser years. It is true that government spending growth has been pulled back this year, but the average is still much higher than that of the previous Government. Because of this lack of discipline over spending, the Hawke Government has had to pull more tax dollars from the pockets of Australians than any previous government in our history. The Hawke Government is the highest taxing government in Australia's history. It is that by whatever measure one wishes to choose.

That is not the end of the story because, despite record taxation, the Government has still not taxed enough to meet its undisciplined spending. So it has had to resort to continual borrowing to balance its books. In three Budgets the Hawke Government has had to borrow no less than $20,000m just to meet this gap betwen its profligate spending and its taxation receipts. That borrowing equals about $1,250 for every man, woman and child in Australia. Per taxpayer the figure is closer to $3,000 each. That borrowing has to be repaid and repaid with interest. This year the interest bill, in a year when interest rates are at their highest ever level, and leaving aside altogether any repayment of the borrowing, is more than we Australians spend on the defence of our country and more than the Federal Government spends on education. This adds up to one very simple fact-that is, the Hawke Labor Government is living way beyond its, and therefore Australia's, means.

The consequences for us all will be dire. They are already starting to surface and I will mention them in some detail as I proceed with my remarks. That leads me to the next of the criteria that I mentioned-namely, whether the Government has taken action to maintain the value of our currency. It is true that inflation, as measured by the consumer price index and most other price indices, fell during the first two years of the Hawke Government. Views differ as to the reasons for this. Personally, I believe the decline was due less to the policies of the Government than to other influences, including the wages freeze which the Hawke Government inherited from the Fraser Government. However, I do not wish to be churlish on this point; I do not need to be. Rather, I just wish to point out four facts. First, even during those two years when Australia's inflation rate was declining, it was still well above that of our major trading partners and, therefore, we were becoming increasingly uncompetive. Secondly, regardless of what happened in those first two years, inflation is now on the increase again in Australia and that is so quite unequivocally. Thirdly, interest rates, after allowing for inflation, are now at their highest level in at least 50 years and probably a century. Finally, the value of the Australian dollar against other currencies has fallen in 1985 more than virtually any other currency has. It has fallen by more than it has fallen in living memory, certainly in our post-war history.

The Australian dollar is now on a slide that it will be very difficult to reverse. This year alone the value of the Australian dollar has fallen by more than one-quarter so that, whereas in January 1985 one needed $4 to buy something overseas, one now needs $5. I say to Senator Cooney that that means that the standard of living of every Australian has fallen. The fall in the Australian dollar this year has been the most significant contributor to the fall in our living standards which has occurred for quite a long time. The fall has been due very largely to the policies of the Hawke Government and to the perception of those policies by the rest of the world. In simple terms, the world is passing judgment on Australia through its lack of confidence in the value and stability of our dollar.

My final criterion on judging of the economic management efficiency of the Government is whether it has provided the right environment for the encouragement of lasting new job creation through economic growth. The Hawke Government does score some points on this criterion, notably for its deregulation of financial institutions-a deregulation, however, which it essentially inherited from the previous Fraser Government.

But the Government fails miserably on other aspects of the criterion, particularly in its blind adherence to the wishes of the trade union movement in wage fixation and its refusal to countenance any deregulation in the wage fixing area despite again the indisputable fact that some greater flexibility in this area would create new jobs and would assist in tackling the crime of youth unemployment in Australia. It is a crime that 25 per cent of our 15 to 19-year-olds are unemployed. It is a crime because it is unnecessary. The Hawke Government bears a very heavy responsibility for this crime.

While I am on the subject of unemployment, in recent days we have heard much about the growth in employment that has occurred in recent times and for which the Government takes credit-credit that I believe is not justly its. But even if one looks at the figures over recent years for the growth in employment in Australia, the Hawke Government does not measure up adequately and comparably with the previous Government. For example, in the three years between November 1978 and November 1981 the average annual increase in employment was 2.2 per cent. In the period May 1984 to May 1985, the highest period of growth to date in the period of the Hawke Government, the increase was also 2.2 per cent. However, the big difference was that most of the employment growth in the period of the Hawke regime was public sector growth whereas under the Fraser Government public sector growth was very limited; by far the overwhelming amount of employment growth in that period was in the private sector. The myth that has been perpetuated that the Hawke Government has done a better job at employment creation than the Fraser Government is simply incorrect on the basis of very simple facts.

Thus, on most of the criteria on which efficiency of government in its economic management can be judged, the present Government measures up very badly both in absolute terms and relative to the previous coalition Government. It is about time that the myth that the Hawke Government is a good economic manager is dispelled once and for all. It simply is not supported by the facts.

I am extremely concerned about where the Australian economy is heading. The reasons for my concern, I guess, are implicit in what I have just said. The problems are there for us all to see. Let me reiterate a few of them. I do so in the presence, I might add, of not one member of the Government in the chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish!
—There is now one Government member. Thank you, Senator, for staying.
—Senator Cooney is still here.
—I apologise to Senator Cooney. This is a very important debate and there are two members of the Government present. There are now three. If I keep talking--
—How many Ministers?

—There is no Minister at the table. There is no Minister in the Senate and there has not been for several minutes. I am, as I said, extremely concerned about where the Australian economy is headed. I have mentioned some of the reasons. I will reiterate a few of them. Inflation is again on the rise. Throughout the whole period of the Hawke Government the inflation rate in Australia has been considerably higher than that experienced by our major trading partners. The gap is widening. We have in this country a system of wage fixation through automatic wage indexation which has locked us into an economic inflationary spiral from which it will be impossible to escape unless that system is changed. There is no suggestion, not even a vague hint on the part of this Government, that that change will occur or even be considered.

SPEECH.PARA: We face a major balance of payments crisis. Despite the largest fall in the value of the Australian dollar since the Second World War, our imports are still increasing while our exports are lagging. There are very good reasons to expect that this situation will continue. We hear from the Government that the traditional J curve effect of a devaluation is still to occur. The lag is longer than has been the case in the past. There are very good reasons to expect for a variety of reasons on this occasion that, that lag will grow longer and longer than we have ever experienced in the past. In the interim, even if the J curve does take effect in time, we will face a very severe mauling of our external account and the value of the Australian dollar. That in turn will further fuel the inflationary spiral and put great pressure on the Government's wages deal with the unions, a deal which was struck without the slightest regard for its effects on business, particularly small business. Interest rates, as I said, are already at their highest level for at least 50 years and they seem certain to increase further.

We face a fundamental foreign debt problem in this country at the moment. Our foreign debt is of the order of $68,000m. At the moment the interest and capital repayments on our foreign debt consume one out of every three export dollars we earn. I am absolutely staggered to hear from the Treasurer and his representative in this chamber, the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh), several times this week that we do not have a foreign debt problem. There is no more serious problem facing this country, and this Government is treating it in an ostrich-like way. Papers released yesterday by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics predict a fall of 26 per cent in the value of rural production in 1985-86, a very small increase in the price received by farmers for their goods and services and a very significant increase in the prices they have to pay for their imports. We have on our hands a rural crisis of considerable magnitude and again the Government seems not even to acknowledge that such a crisis exists.

What should we do about the problems of which I have been speaking tonight? I would not for one second pretend that the government of the day has the answers to these problems readily in its hands. That would be to fall into the trap into which this Government has fallen in a massive way over the last two and a half years by saying to the Australian people: `She'll be right. We, the Government, know the problems; we will be able to fix them'. That is the greatest con and crime that has been perpetrated on this nation for a long time. It takes away from individual Australians the feeling that they need to develop their own enterprise, incentive and effort. Governments cannot solve our problems but they can set an environment in which we can better solve them.

What would I do if I were advising the Government? The first thing that must be done is for the Government to take a closer account of its own spending. If the Government is not prepared to exercise greater discipline and restraint in its spending, none of the other problems of which I have been speaking tonight will be solvable. The Government must relook at its whole policy towards wage fixation. An added degree of flexibility must be introduced into the Australian wages system, otherwise our uncompetitiveness will continue unabated, regardless of what other measures we may take. If that occurs, we will go further down the road of economic decline. I was very interested to read this week a report of Professor Helen Hughes's first Boyer lecture for this week in which she said:
Unemployed Australians would be looking for laboring jobs in rapidly growing Asian countries in another 30 to 50 years unless present trends could be changed . . .
She pointed out:

. . . Australia, which had the world's highest per capita income a century ago, had the slowest growth of any industrial country since 1900 and was now fifteenth on the wealth index of developed nations.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the long free lunch.

—It is a free lunch induced by those on the other side of this chamber who have conned the Australian public into believing that governments can do everything for them and that people do not have to do anything for themselves.
—It is always the worker. Why do you not pick on anyone else?
—It has nothing to do with an attack on the worker. If Senator Bolkus thought a bit more about Australia and a bit less about Latin America his side of politics might be a little better.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I resent that inference. I am concerned about Australia. This man is here to represent only one faction within Australia-one elite group-and he has the gall to accuse me of not being representative of all Australians. I ask him to withdraw.
—There is no point of order.
—In future I will listen with interest to what the honourable senator says about the situation in Australia. I must have been missing something.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government must look again at its tax proposals. The whole thrust of the tax proposals is anti-business; it is particularly anti-small small business and anti-incentive. If we as a nation think we will grow and provide the goods and services that we want to provide as a caring and compassionate nation and we do not provide the incentive for the creation of income and wealth in this country, we are sadly deluding ourselves. Above all, this Government needs to show some leadership and a sense of direction to this nation. The problems we are facing in Australia are not just the Government's fault in a policy sense, critical though I am of those policies. Even more important is the failure of the Government to show leadership and to say to the Australian people: `We want growth, prosperity and job creation in this country'. Until it does that and adopts policies which are in line with that sense of direction, the problems to which I have alluded tonight, which I believe are of greater concern to this country than we have had in a generation, the problems will not go away; they will worsen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1985-86, the Appropriation Bill (No. 2) 1985-86 and the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill, which are before the Senate tonight, are Bills of appropriation which give effect to decisions made by the Government in the Budget. Therefore, I think it is important to commence my remarks by referring to the Budget-a Budget which was previewed by the Opposition, before it was delivered, as a disaster for Australia. In fact, on the very day the Budget was brought down, the former Treasurer in the Fraser Government, now the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard, forecast that the Government would be lucky to get the Budget deficit under $6 billion.
—The discredited former Treasurer.

—That is right, the discredited former Treasurer of the Fraser era, now the Leader of the Opposition and economic expert, who is charting the course for what the Government should do with the economy-a discredited course because it is no more than a regurgitation of the Fraser formula. He forecast on the very day of the Budget that the deficit this government would bring down would be above the $6 billion mark. Of course, to his chagrin and to the surprise and annoyance of the Opposition, the Budget deficit in the papers delivered by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in August was $5.9 billion. That illustrates the paucity of economic forecasting and talent in the Opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: Since the advent of the Hawke Government on the treasury bench in March 1983 we have seen a government that has been concerned to manage the economy by giving clear signals to the market. It has moved in a confident and assured way to deliver upon those signals, and on all the major indicators it has always over-achieved on what it has forecast as its direction. When the Government assumed power in 1983 it set out, in the midst of an economic crisis, to expand the economy and create growth by establishing a deficit Budget. It did so confidently, knowing that it had in place a prices and incomes accord which would enable it to run an expansionary economic line and to hold down wages by virtue of an agreement with the trade union movement, and to deliver, as it did in 1984, a halving of inflation, an increase in employment, a reduction in unemployment, an expanding economy, and a reduction in industrial disputes. It was on the basis of that economic performance that the Government was re-elected at the end of last year for yet another term.

Whatever else is said by members of the Opposition, one fact remains true: Despite the whimperings of our opponents about the breaking of the drought and about international factors this Government has got itself organised on the economy and has managed to deliver growth rates year after year. So we are looking now at a sustained period of economic growth which will create jobs, provide employment for young school leavers and ensure that the Australian economy continues to expand, win new markets overseas, and regenerate itself. That achievement was recognised last month by the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, when its Secretary-General, Mr Paye, visited Australia and complimented this Government on its economic achievements. In particular, he singled out the accord as being the fundamental premise upon which this government had built its economic strategy.

However, quite apart from the general macro- economic framework put down in Budgets, this Government has not shrunk from the tougher and more courageous decisions on the economy. One of the most fundamental injustices perpetrated by many years of conservative rule in this country has been that the tax system was never reformed. What we had during the whole of the Fraser years, and the previous period of the Holt, Gorton and Menzies years, was a tax system that became more and more unjust. We had taxation scales at both average and marginal rates, which were designed to tax the wealthiest in the economy, being applied to ordinary average wage earners, and as inflation has bitten and wages and salaries have increased they have moved further and further up the scale into higher marginal rates. So now we are looking at marginal rates of taxation, which were envisaged for the most wealthy in society, being applied to the average.

We have seen as well in the breakdown of the taxation system that increasingly the share of tax paid to public revenues has been borne by middle and low wage earners and that the wealthy have escaped their obligations to the public purse. In fact, it does not come to me to say it, but many commentators in both the economic and taxation fields have remarked that, under the regime of taxation that applied in this country, the contribution to tax by the wealthy was merely a voluntary one. Since the announcement on 19 September of the Government's tax package, we have heard complaints from the Opposition in which it has selectively chosen targets to pick off within a total symmetrical and balanced package.

We know, of course, that in any tax package that is honest, fair and just there will be new areas of tax and that those who have escaped their liabilities will be brought into the tax net. I believe that the most disgusting thing that we have seen from the Opposition is its defence of those who have been tax avoiders, those who have excaped the net of paying their due worth in taxation and those who over the years have practised the art of avoiding their obligations to the community while imposing higher and higher burdens on ordinary average Australians. That defence of privilege is the most disgusting and obnoxious feature of all of the speeches that have come from the Opposition benches on taxation.

I think this Government has taken the most courageous course in tax reform that we have seen from any government of this country. There have been some criticisms of the fact that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer chose to publish their options and to select their preferred option from among them. They then chose to call the community of Australia to a summit and to consult with that community to see what the people of Australia thought about the various options. On the basis of the feedback delivered to it by unions, employers, the welfare sector and all other interested groups in the economy, the Government then modelled a package for reform which not only reflects Government priorities but also reflects the wishes and desires of the broader community. The tax package that this Government has brought forward does exactly that. Yet, we have not seen from the Opposition any comprehensive reply; we have not yet seen from the Opposition any comprehensive rebuttal; and we have not yet seen from the Opposition any alternative package. What we have seen from the Opposition is constant sniping, nit-picking and pandering to the emotions of small privileged groups in society which want to protect their particular tax rorts. That must fundamentally demonstrate the hypocrisy of the position taken by the Opposition.

The tax package that this Government is bringing forward is a package which introduces some new taxes. We heard Senator Short say tonight that the capital gains tax envisaged in this package is reprehensible and attacks small business. Of course, the truth about capitals gains tax is that Australia is almost unique among the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries-an organisation of the most advanced industrialised and economically developed countries in the world-in not having a capital gains tax. It is to our shame that we have this major gap in our taxation regime. Yet this tax has been attacked tonight as being somehow a disincentive for small business. What Senator Short failed to argue, and what the Opposition has failed to argue, is that this tax seemingly is not a disincentive in West Germany, it does not deter the Japanese from re-investment and it does not fight back the private entrepreneurs in Canada from seeking to maximise their gains. A capital gains tax applies in the United States of America and that country's economy is burgeoning. A similar situation exists in France and Britain.

TALK.START.PARA: —Opposition senators are leaving the chamber.

—It seems that the Opposition benches are being depleted at a fast rate. While this tax is not reprehensible, is not a disincentive and is regarded as a proper tax in comparable OECD countries, we hear from the Opposition that uniquely it is somehow a reprehensible tax in Australia. Of course, the truth about the capital gains tax is that there is no substance to the sort of emotional stampeding that the Opposition has engaged in trying to argue against the capital gains tax in the community, the fear campaign it has engaged in to pretend that it will encompass a wider area than it really will and the claim that it will affect ordinary people when in fact it will only affect a small elite group of investors.

SPEECH.PARA: The capital gains tax that this Government has introduced will tax real capital gains, which is to say that the value of properties purchased after the Treasurer's announcement on 18 September will be indexed according to the consumer price index and any gains in value beyond the level of the indexation of the CPI will be taxed. Those gains will then be taxed at the average company and marginal tax rates. There will be provision for write-offs. The family home will be exempt. The family home on a farming property will also be exempt. Certain owner-use equipment that goes with the family home-furniture and other provisions-will also be exempt.

We have in Australia a capital gains tax which by world standards is a soft tax but which by equity standards in Australia is a necessary tax. It is a tax that addresses the fundamental reforms that we have sought in the economy-reforms based on the concept that a tax system must be efficient, equitable and address the avoidance and evasion which has been occurring in the economy. It is a matter of fact that the coalition never bothered to do anything about avoidance and evasion until such time as it became a public scandal in this country. Because public sentiment was such that there was shock and outrage at the level of avoidance by a small group of privileged people, then and only then was it moved. The scandals that afflicted the Opposition during its period of government are now legend. The history of the rorts being worked out of the Perth office of the Attorney-General's Department and so on is now legend as typifying the sorts of things that were occurring in this country because the Opposition lacked the will to approach tax reform in any way at all, let alone in the comprehensive way in which this Government has approached it, addressing the basic precepts of justice, efficiency and a fair deal for all taxpayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —They left it in the bottom drawer.

—They left it in the bottom drawer: that is right. The other thing that the Opposition has turned its fire on in recent times has been the wages accord. It is remarkable that it has chosen that as a target because the accord has underscored the basic economic strategy of the Government. The Government has achieved, as I said earlier, a halving of inflation, a reduction in unemployment, an increase in employment, an expanding economy year after year, a track of sustained economic growth and as well we have sustained an increase in profitability in the private sector. All of those things during the period of the so-called private enterprise government-the conservative government-were never achieved. In fact, the reverse was achieved and, indeed, in the last year of that government negative industrial growth occurred. We as a government have succeeded in achieving those things and we have achieved them because of the accord. The accord, of course, is a document that stands as a compact between the Government and the Australian Council of Trade Unions. It is a continually negotiated and renegotiated agreement. The accord mark 2 concluded earlier this year has reinforced the accord and has meant that we are now able to look forward to a continuing period of industrial expansion.

SPEECH.PARA: Today's reports and yesterday's reports about the fall in the value of the Australian dollar have been trumpeted from the Opposition benches as if they somehow indicate a flaw in the economic management by the Government. The truth is that they indicate a flaw certainly, but the flaw does not lie with the Government; it lies with those on the international currency exchanges who do not understand how the economy in Australia works. As the Sydney Morning Herald reported in its editorial today, the fact that the New York currency exchange learnt that the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission in Australia has given a 3.8 per cent wage increase to wage and salary earners across the board and that our external debt is high was enough to panic the exchange dealers. What we have seen over recent weeks is the Treasurer of Australia travelling abroad, visiting New York, London and other international centres explaining that not only is the Australian economy strong but also that it is verging on overheating. That, more than anything, indicates that we have a sound economic future.

The reduction in the value of the Australian dollar compared with the value of the United States dollar is a passing blip on the statistics of the exchange rate. As soon as the exchange markets learn to be more sophisticated in judging the performance of the Australian economy, as they will as this economy continues to expand over time, and realise its 5 on 5 per cent growth rates year on year, their judgment will improve and we will not see these wild fluctuations. The editorial in the Sydney Morning Herald counselled the Treasurer today. It asked what he should do. He should do nothing. He should hold firm and pursue the line of economic strategy that this Government has embarked upon. Indeed the Treasurer, just last month, at the Canberra Economic Society said that what we are witnessing in Australia is a troughing out at the bottom of the J-curve. That might be a peculiar Keatingism, but it does explain very succinctly the fact that what we have seen with the devaluation of the Australian dollar is the effect of the J-curve applying immediately. The effect of the J-curve is that with immediate devaluation the cost of imports rises straight away. We pay those higher costs and our current account deficit blows out as a temporary feature. That current account deficit blows out because of the higher costs of imports and the lag in the renegotiation of export prices and contracts.

If we are not yet we are very close to being at the bottom of the J-curve there. We are now looking forward, with the renegotiation of export prices, to a sustained recovery and a reeling back of our current account deficit as not only the price of our exports increases but the volume of the sales of our exports increases as well. I now hear the barking and baying voices of Opposition senators who want to contest the facts and argue fantasy against reality. We are now approaching a time in which we will see the reeling back of that current account deficit as the J-curve goes on its long, sustained upward climb. Opposition senators have tried to harp on this matter and tried to pretend that we are not troughing out of the J-curve, as the Treasurer puts it. They want us to panic, they refuse to face reality. They want to run away from what is a responsible economic line and throw caution to the wind. This Government is not going to be panicked; this Government is not going to be stampeded. This Government is going to stick with its economic philosophies and reap the benefits of standing fast and not panicking.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are we going up the little bit or the big bit of the J-curve?

—That is a very good question. Senator Tate has asked whether we are going up the little bit or the big bit of the J-curve. Everyone is familiar with the shape of a `J'. We have gone down the little bit; we are at the bottom of the curve and we are going right up the big bit. We are going right up the big bit shortly in a sustained recovery and a reeling back of our current account deficit. If Senator Tate has any other questions about the J-curve, could he please put them on notice.

SPEECH.PARA: The renegotiation of the accord mark 2 has also enabled this Government to achieve a quite unique approach to economic policy formulation. As soon as the Australian dollar was devalued following the float, we heard from the Opposition braying, panic-stricken calls and calls for the discounting of wages to offset the loss of the value in the Australian dollar. This Goverment has achieved a renegotiation in accord mark 2 to provide a discounting of 2 per cent in the next wages round. We have been able to negotiate with the Australian Council of Trade Unions to offset some of the negative effects of the devaluation and lock in its constructive effects. It has been a trade off. If one were to look at the winners and losers of the trade off one would find that there are precious few losers. The Australian economy as a whole is advantaged. The accord mark 2 puts very much on the agenda the introduction of a national superannuation scheme to provide the aging and greying population of Australia with security in their old age, the ability to retire earlier and, when they do retire, the ability to live at higher levels of income than pension rates would afford.

I believe that the accord mark 2 will be an historic document in the sense that, once its full benefits are checked in, the population of Australia will benefit by having a superannuation scheme to which most contribute with a superannuation net installed under it by the Government. At long last the aging population of Australia can look forward with some security to the future. In the past and at present we have found that superannuation has been the province of the higher paid worker rather than of the blue collar and lower paid worker. At least 40 per cent of the population are without superannuation cover. However, in the next few years that situation will be wiped out and all will be covered. That will be a distinct achievement of the accord mark 2.

Before the braying and carping criticism comes from the Opposition benches it should also be mentioned that the accord mark 2 confers tax cuts on the wage and salary earners of this country to try to redistribute the level of taxation which has to be paid by wage and salary earners, reducing it to a reasonable level. Average wage and salary earners can look forward in September of next year to receiving tax cuts of between $8 and $12, and, in 1987, of between $14 and $22. Those tax cuts, which are real value tax cuts, will also be conferred on wage and salary earners by virtue of the accord. Commentators on the Opposition benches frequently fail to recognise that those tax cuts, together with wage increases, put purchasing power in the pockets of consumers. We are then able to see ordinary wage and salary earners, most of whom spend all the money they receive, spending money again in purchasing goods and services produced in Australia and overseas. Every extra good or service that is sold by virtue of that enhances purchasing power in the end creates another job for another Australian, lifts our employment levels and provides a future and perspective for young Australians coming onto the wage market. That aspect of wages is always, in my experience, avoided.

The Opposition has argued against all of these trends but what, in fact, is its record? What is its alternative? Almost weekly we hear of the changes in and different predictions about what the Opposition's wages and labour policy might be. If one over-arches all the comments that are made, the conclusion one comes to is that some sort of policy will emanate from the Opposition about the deregulation of the wages market. No one is quite sure to what extent. No one is quite sure how voluntary it will be. But in some sense and in some way there will be deregulation. If one goes back in history to consult the last occasion on which there was a walking away from wage indexation one finds that it was in 1981-82. In that period, the year ending March 1982, we saw a wages explosion in this country of 17 per cent, in a contracting economy of growing unemployment and negative industrial growth. Nonetheless we saw in Australia the embryonic possibilities of Australia following the British track, that is, a track in which there are high and growing levels of unemployment, wages and inflation. We saw that possibility being addressed in Australia in the recent period of Liberal-National Party rule. The accord has contained the reasonable expectations of Australian wage and salary earners, guaranteed them that their purchasing power will be retained and prevented the wages stampede that a deregulated market would have produced.
Debate interrupted.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., under sessional order, I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad that Senator Gareth Evans, the Minister representing the Special Minister of State, is in the chamber because in a sense the matter I want to raise tonight is a question to him. Some comments need to be made, which make this matter inappropriate to raise during Question Time. I refer to the account which the organisers of the World Cup Athletics have received from the Australian Federal Police for about $250,000, representing the alleged costs of the police presence at the very successful World Cup Athletics.

SPEECH.PARA: Canberra was awarded these games at a meeting in Jamaica in April of 1982, some 3 1/2 years before they were held. It is necessary to have 3 1/2 years to organise games of these dimensions. A lot of budgeting had to be done and many other matters attended to. It was not until 13 August 1985 that the organisers received a letter from the Commissioner of Police advising that the cost of the required police presence would be in the vicinity of $250,000. There is an issue involved as to whether or not the user pays principle ought to apply to the presence of police in any situation, and I shall come to that. If that were the case, I suggest that to raise the matter in August of 1985, only weeks before the event was held, was quite irresponsible. This Government had 2 1/2 years in which to come to this decision and to advise the organisers. They could then have budgeted for it and could have been in a position to pay the bill. That it was raised in August, long after the time that the price of the tickets was set and many had been sold, has put the organisers in a position where, I suggest, it is probably unlikely that they would be able to find that sum of money and, in any event, the request for payment should be withdrawn.

I come to the question of whether or not we have moved into applying the user pays policy for police. It might be very easy to identify the World Cup Athletics as a suitable organisation to hit and to say that it should pay up. Will this apply to all sport? Will it apply to amateur and professional sport alike, in which case the World Cup Athletics may very well be excluded? It goes further than that. From time to time in Canberra there are demonstrations and marches. I believe that most people would think that those demonstrations ought to be allowed to take place and that it is a proper function of police to be there. On occasions, we have had nuclear groups marching. Quite recently, parents of school children marched from Civic to Parliament House in protest at the Government's cutback in education funding. It was a quite orderly affair. There was never any suggestion that it would be anything otherwise. Because of the numbers of people involved and the numbers of children accompanying them, it was inevitable, and appropriately so, that the police would be there.

Are people to be charged if they want to march in this fashion? Will they have to pay the money up front, so to speak? What will happen if they do not pay? At present, we have a very unsightly demonstration outside the South African Embassy, which, as the Minister would know, is an illegal assembly on Commonwealth land. No one would doubt that there are embassies in Canberra which, because of the provisions of the Vienna Convention, require some police presence to honour that convention. Because of what the Government has allowed to remain outside the South African Embassy it has been necessary to have more police there than would normally be the case. Are the demonstrators there to be charged for what they have caused?

These are serious questions and the community is entitled to know what criteria are used to determine who should pay for police presence. They should have been announced by now. I have not raised this issue before because I thought that we would have seen something from the Government as to the new arrangements and who would be affected by them. It is a serious question, and I hope that if the Minister is not able to give a full answer tonight he will do so at the earliest opportunity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I wish to make some remarks concerning a friend and colleague of mine, Jim Gale. Jim Gale died recently. His passing was most untimely. Jim was the endorsed Australian Labor Party candidate for the Federal division of Sturt last year and only last November fought a very energetic campaign for the Party in the Sturt division. He attempted very energetically to represent Labor in another place. Jim was endorsed by the Labor Party at very short notice to contest the Sturt division for Labor. He campaigned throughout the district very actively and energetically and at the election represented Labor supporters in the district extremely well. I certainly was very pleased and honoured to work with Jim in his Sturt campaign last November and December.

SPEECH.PARA: Most importantly, Jim Gale was a tireless fighter in the community for peace and equality. He was known throughout Australia as the National Convener of the Campaign Against Racial Exploitation, known as CARE. His wife, Irene, was and still is its Secretary-Treasurer. Together they have dedicated themselves to the struggle against racism both in Australia and abroad. Jim and Irene Gale have worked selflessly towards the ideal of a world where all men and women are able to live as equals. Of course, all deaths are untimely, but Jim's was especially so, I believe, because the on-going struggle against racism and apartheid in South Africa is beginning to force changes there. I believe that it is a great pity that he will not see the ultimate results of that struggle.

Jim Gale was born in New Zealand. He supported himself through university by working on the wharves and in the factories. Jim and Irene and their family came to Australia in 1971. He worked as a teacher in primary and secondary schools and at colleges of advanced education. Jim was a lecturer in English at the Salisbury College of Advanced Education in Adelaide. At all stages of his working life he was an active union member. His sincerity and commitment were apparent to everyone who met him. Jim's loss is felt by all in the Labor Party in Adelaide but most sadly by Irene, his wife, and the children, Roger, Jenny, Stephen, Linda and Owen. We shall all miss him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I simply indicate that I will take on board the comments that have been made by Senator Reid and refer them to the Special Minister of State (Mr Young). As to the sad death of the late Jim Gale, I simply endorse on behalf of the Government the expressions of sympathy and condolence that have been made by Senator Maguire and record my appreciation, certainly, of the work that he did during his life for the cause of racial equality.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 10.39 p.m.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answers to questions were circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 28 February 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Was the Department of Defence responsible for the publication of the booklet `Nuclear weapons-their effects and your protection' which bears the Australian insignia and the words `Department of Defence Natural Disasters Organisation' on its front cover; if so, what was the cost of producing this publication and who were the authors.

(2) Is the Minister for Defence aware that statements in this publication are directly opposed to the Australian Labor Party (ALP) platform, in particular, the view expressed on page 28, section 5.1, of `Nuclear weapons-their effects and your protection', which states that: `Australia is fortunate. In the event of global nuclear war, we would not have the risk that northern-hemisphere countries have of being at the centre of conflict or being blanketted with fallout,' and contradicts Section 6 of the ALP platform.
(3) Does the Minister agree with the statement in the above booklet on page 28, section 5.3, that in any nuclear attack `. . . most Australians would not be directly affected'.

(4) Does the Government, and in particular the Minister for Defence, support the statement on page 1, section 7, of `Nuclear weapons-their effects and your protection' that Australians who are concerned about the hazards of nuclear weapons explosions are `being hysterical and holding to exaggerated notions.'

(5) Has the Minister seen or is he aware of work by such defence experts as P. J. Crutzen, R. P. Turco, Carl Sagan and A. B. Pittock, all of whom have concluded that, far from the effects of nuclear war being contained, they may well be catastrophic globally.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. The cost was $9,370 for 42,000 copies. As acknowledged on the last page of the booklet, the contents are based on publications printed by Her Majesty's Stationery Office (UK) and the Oak Ridge National Laboratory (USA). Contributions were also received from the Commonwealth Department of Health and State and Territory Emergency Services.

(2) As the ALP Platform recognises, it would be unrealistic to suppose that Australia would not be affected by a global nuclear conflict, and that is not being suggested in the extract quoted by Senator Childs. The Statement referred to sought to point out that the scale of direct damage which Australia might suffer in a nuclear war should be less than in northern hemisphere countries, because of our geographical remoteness from the areas in which such a conflict would most likely be focussed. That is realistic and compatible with the ALP position. The publication referred to was intended to provide the best technical information available at the time of printing.

(3) The publication states `Any nuclear attack on a populated industrial area would result in many casualties, the number depending on precautions taken, the time of day or night and many other factors. In all probability, however, most Australians would not be directly affected', this accords with past and present strategic assessments of nuclear threat to Australia.

(4) The sentence referred to by the honourable senator in fact states: `knowledge of the potential hazards of nuclear weapons explosions will also help dispel the more hysterical or exaggerated notions held by many people.' This does not imply that anyone who is concerned about the hazards of nuclear weapons explosions is either hysterical or holding to exaggerated notions. The Government treats these matters very seriously indeed. That is why it is important that the public should have access to information on this subject.

(5) Yes. I am also aware that there remain many uncertainties in this area. For example, the US National Academy of Sciences has recently observed that `the pervasive uncertainties in the data and the limited validity of the atmospheric models used to date imply that some future study, conducted at a time when the data and models have been improved, could produce quite different analyses and conclusions'. The Academy also observed that `it is particularly difficult to assess the potential effects of the baseline war on the atmosphere of the northern tropics and southern hemisphere. Although southern hemisphere effects would be much less extensive, significant amounts of dust and smoke could drift to and across the equator as early as a few weeks after a nuclear exchange.' There are of course real grounds for concern, and as in all these matters, we would like to see more informed discussion. To this end, we are reviewing the publication referred to by the honourable senator to see how it can be improved.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice on 20 August 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister for Health aware that organochlorine pesticides such as aldrin, dieldrin, heptachlor and chlordane, which produce neurotoxic effects, are readily available for domestic use in Australia although they have been severely restricted overseas.

(2) Is the Minister familiar with the wealth of overseas research, and the work of Australian organisations such as the Total Environment Centre, which indicates the harmful effects of such chemicals.
(3) Can the Minister advise what action he intends taking to prohibit the distribution of the dangerous chemicals referred to in (1) above in order to protect the health of Australian citizens.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The overseas restrictions on organochlorine insecticides, aldrin, dieldrin, heptachlor and chlordane, vary considerably. In Australia, restrictions on their availability and use are as determined by State and Territory authorities. All are classified as Schedule 6 poisons in the Uniform Poisons Standard of the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) in view of their hazard potential.

(2) Organochlorine pesticides have been of concern to environmental health authorities for some time. My Department and the National Health and Medical Research Council support the long-standing policy of the Australian Agricultural Council that the use of these materials be phased out as alternatives become available. A further review of their potential health hazards, taking into account the most recent toxicological studies, is in progress. Information now provided by the Total Environment Centre will be considered fully in the current review as will other relevant information.
(3) The question of further restriction of the availability and use of organochlorine pesticides will be considered when the outcome of the current review is known.

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: School of Public Health and Tropical Medicine

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 21 August 1985 (Hansard, page 86) Senator Reynolds asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Health, a question without notice concerning the location of the School of Public Health and Tropical Medicine within the Australian National University and the return of the Tropical Medicine Research Unit to northern Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Health has provided the following information:

The honourable senator will be aware that the School of Public Health and Tropical Medicine is now part of the recently established Australian Institute of Health. In order to best meet the objectives of the Australian Institute of Health, consideration has been given to the possible relocation of the activities of the School of Public Health and Tropical Medicine. One of the options considered was the relocation of a number of these activities to Canberra in association with the well established research facilities at the Australian National University and this matter has been discussed openly with staff in the School. However, no final decision on relocation has been taken.

With respect to the question of the re-establishment of a Tropical Medicine Research Unit in northern Australia, I would draw the attention of the honourable senator to a statement by the Prime Minister on 24 September, 1985 following the meeting of Cabinet in Townsville which indicated that I have commissioned two consultants, Dr Kerr White and Mr Mick Reid, to undertake an independent review of the appropriate arrangements for public health and tropical health teaching and research requirements for Australia. The terms of reference include a specific reference to examine a proposal for the establishment of a Tropical Research Unit in Townsville. I anticipate that a report will be available for consideration by the Government at the end of this year.
